B00003CXZ4|5.0|Not only is this movie an enigma, it is also rich thematically.  Teddy, \\"the liar,\\" often tells it like it is and becomes the audience's source for actually figuring out what is going on.  The movie plays with time (reverse chronology) and asks us how genuine are our own memories. Do we filter memory like Leonard does (b/f and after the tragedy) in order to make ourselves feel happier?  How many of our memories are reliable?  To what extent are our memories self-serving, interpretive, and/or inventive?<br />It took me awhile after the movie to synthesize all that was going on--very interesting and will have its viewers on the edge of their seats. Humor is interspersed throughout the movie for the much-needed comic relief.
037571457X|4.0|Most admirers of the Persepolis books see them as a heart-warming tale of a young girl's struggle to grow up and stay true to self in the face of Islamic repression. Satrapi, in her first volume, makes herself look like Ramona Quimby, the \\"little sparkler\\" from the children's series that charmed American readers years ago.<br /><br />  But this ain't no kid's funny-book. If Persepolis were a movie, it would rate a hard \\"R\\" for depictions of sexual situations, torture, violence, nudity, depictions of bathroom functions, and plenty of bad language.<br /><br />  Even so, many thousands of American and European fans today take Marjane Satrapi to their hearts, especially the little version. Again, we believe it's a Ramona Quimby thing. In other words, Satrapi's audience, mostly females between the ages of 18 and 40, convince themselves that she is just like them: young, smart, spunky and cute, with solid middle-class though not middle-American) credentials, making lots of mistakes and learning from them while making her way in a crazy world.<br /><br />  But anybody who knows a little about the Middle East will instantly recognize that's not exactly right: there are certain factors, below the radar of most North Americans, that critically affect how Satrapi's story must be interpreted and understood.<br /><br />  First of all, little Marji and her family are not really modern middle-class types as we understand them in the USA. These people are stone-cold blue-bloods: the kind of people the Egyptians call pashas, and the Bostonians, brahmans.  Marji's great grand-dad on her mother's side was the last emperor of the dynasty toppled by the first Pahlevi ruler with British help; when her father tells her the story, he emphasizes, with some indignation, that Reza Shah was just an illiterate low-ranking officer.<br /><br />  Nevertheless, Marji's dad manages to settle down comfortably under both the Pahlevis and the \\"Islamic Republic.\\" He has a place in the \\"chic\\" part of town and an expensive car. When the Revolutionary Guards catch him with wine on his breath, he has the bribes handy. If his only daughter smacks her principal, he can get her into another school. He and his wife won't ever leave Iran to seek the \\"freedom\\" of the West; he'd rather keep what he has than become a cabbie in the USA.<br /><br />  Marji's family are the descendants of princes, and committed Marxists. For the Satrapis, there is no contradiction: \\"Only a prince (in Iran) can allow himself to have a conscience.\\" Marji's parents do not believe in Allah, but buy her books and comics explaining basic communist theory.<br /><br />  Stay alert and it becomes obvious that Marjane Satrapi really isn't a recovering Muslimah at all; she was never taught to be one in the first place. For her, Islam will always be that foreign religion that the Arab invaders imposed upon her gentle Zoroastrian ancestors.<br /><br />  And so,\\"Islam\\" does not interest Satrapi; she does not really care whether Khumayni's government by ayatullah \\"philosopher-kings\\" makes Islam work, or makes the lives of people she doesn't know better. Instead, she judges the Islamic Republic by what it does to her family, its friends, and to her. Towards the end of Volume 1, 14-year-old Marji has the courage to rebuke a teacher who claims that the Islamic Republic of Iran (the same entity that shot her Uncle Anoosh) did not hold political prisoners. Unfortunately, Satrapi slips from this height, and starts despising the Khumayni r&eacute;gime mainly because it won't let her have make-up and Nikes.<br /><br />  Of course, most of Satrapi's western admirers will think this is courageously standing up to the narcs of Islamic repression. However, a more critical reading of Marjane Satrapi's young life raises some nagging questions: do her collisions with Muslim and non-Muslim authority figures throughout betray a love for liberty and the Rights of Man, as her parents and grandmother seem to think? Or do they represent the whims of a spoiled young princess, the only daughter of a rich family used to getting her way?<br /><br />  As Part 1 ends,things get too hot for Marji in her neighborhood; and her parents send her away to Europe. A cynical reader might wonder: are they getting her out of the way because her big mouth and out-of-control behavior threaten to mess up their lives-we're not being mean; the issue raises its scaly head, briefly, in the second volume.<br /><br />  Even so, both volumes of Persepolis are worthwhile reading for concerned adult Muslims. They badly need to understand the heads of people who don't like Islam. Satrapi's book in itself is a sincere testimony, from one convinced that she is telling her truth about life and politics in the Islamic Republic of Iran. That assumes, of course, that readers take the usual precautions with autobiographers, who often indulge in justifying themselves or settling old scores.a spoiled young princess, the only daughter of a rich family used to getting her way?  <br />     As Part 1 ends,things get too hot for Marji in her neighborhood; and her parents send her away to Europe. They badly need to understand the heads of people who don't like Islam. That assumes, of course, that readers take the usual precautions with autobiographers, who often indulge in justifying themselves or settling old scores.
B0009IW9DE|5.0|While 1985 seminal SCARECROW remains the signature John Mellencamp album, THE LONESOME JUBILEE, in my opinion, is his greatest musical achievement.  Both discs have a lot to say, lyrically speaking.  But whereas Scarecrow scored the messages with 60's-influenced rock, Jubilee expands this sound to include more rustic instrumentation.  The result is a pleasure to hear, as Mellencamp and his band effortlessly (or so it seems) make every song a keeper.  Even potentially heavy-handed material such as \\"We Are the People\\" and \\"Empty Hands\\" (with one of my favorite lines, \\"They say people get what they deserve/But Lord, sometimes it's much worse than that\\") is served up with such conviction that it's hard to fault their earnestness.<br /><br />Unreleased material (the bonus track) is, of course, always welcome.  But as someone has already mentioned, it sure would have been nice to have the b-sides from Jubilee's singles on the disc.  Or even John's VERY SPECIAL CHRISTMAS contribution, \\"I Saw Mommy Kissing Santa Claus,\\" which was released shortly after this album came out.<br /><br />But I've still got my treasured 45's, so I can live with it.  In any event, if you only get one Mellencamp remastered disc, this is the one.

0679736646|5.0|I have just withdrawn my earlier review for this novel because Amazon does not like the same item to be reviewed by one reviewer more than once. But I have just reread this novel and the light of my life experience has exposed so much more in it. Philip Dick is my absolute favourite writer - ahead of such others as Ivan Turgenev, Joseph Conrad, WH Hudson, Anna Kavan, Mary Shelley.... Not only is it his mind-bending plot lines, his dead pan humour, his gruelling descriptions of disaster (almost minimalist but enormously effective) but also his research - philosophy, theology, psychology. When I read 'Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep' he taught me all about empathy.<br /><br />This novel is about a psychopath - hidden until the very end, but impacting everywhere. There is a remedy for the disastrous personal collapses the psychopath triggers and how I wish I had just such a remedy for a colleague of mine! Not for me, but for her and all those who work and live around her. I suffered a recent bout of bullying in the workplace which alerted me to the fact that this bully might be something much worse and his impact in our community of workers may be much wider than just against me.<br /><br />By chance a television program alerted me to a book, just published, called 'Working with Monster' by John Clarke and published by Random House Australia. Reading Clarke's book - not only about the workplace psychopath but also about his or her victims - has shown me how well Philip Dick plotted these characteristics into his novel. There was, for me, another inexplicable link between my workplace candidate psychopath (I cannot diagnose it - I am not a professional in these matters) and 'Ubik' - so spooky as to suggest to me that there are messages for me in this - but from where?<br /><br />'Ubik'is a great novel, and its foundations are very sound. Read it and laugh at Joe Chip's fight with the autonomous doors and other devices, be fascinated at the wonderful pen picture of Wendy Wright, be horrified at Joe Chip's stagger up the stairs under the unsympathetic eyes of Pat Conley, follow the speculations of the characters in this thriller that takes you back from the future of 1990 (as it was imagined by Philip Dick in 1969) all the way back to 1939.<br /><br />My heading to this review is the question posed by so many psychopath's victims - and it is a quote from 'Ubik'.<br /><br />What did I write in the earlier review?<br /><br />*********************<br />After scanning some reviews of 'Ubik' I was appalled. There are people who believe Philip K Dick couldn't write, couldn't plot a story!!!! Now I don't claim to be a technical purist in these matters but I can certainly tell great writing when I read it. Here are two things to look out for in 'Ubik'. Firstly there is a character description of Wendy Wright that starts 'As always, when the opportunity arose, Joe took a long astute look at the girl whom, if he could have managed it, he would have had as his mistress, or even better, his wife.' and ends with '...... She had too much control over herself and outside reality for that.' And then there is the chilling collapse of Joe Chip at the start of Chapter 13, watched by an apparently unsympathetic Pat Conley.<br />I recommend those who have not yet experienced 'Ubik' to read it with an open mind and a preparedness to let the plot take you for a ride - whatever you do, don't try to make your 'solution' to the twists and turns as they unfold THE only possible resolution. Philip Dick will almost certainly take you another direction.<br /><br />******************************<br /><br />other recommended reading:<br />John Clarke - Working with Monsters<br />Philip Dick - A Maze of Death<br />Philip Dick - A Scanner Darkly<br />Philip Dick - Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep?ied at Joe Chip's stagger up the stairs under the unsympathetic eyes of Pat Conley, follow the speculations of the characters in this thriller that takes you back from the future of 1990 (as it was imagined by Philip Dick in 1969) all the way back to 1939.    My heading to this review is the question posed by so many psychopath's victims - and it is a quote from 'Ubik'.    What did I write in the earlier review?    *********************  After scanning some reviews of 'Ubik' I was appalled. There are people who believe Philip K Dick couldn't write, couldn't plot a story!!!! Now I don't claim to be a technical purist in these matters but I can certainly tell great writing when I read it. Here are two things to look out for in 'Ubik'. Firstly there is a character description of Wendy Wright that starts 'As always, when the opportunity arose, Joe took a long astute look at the girl whom, if he could have managed it, he would have had as his mistress, or even better, his wife.' and ends with '...... She had too much control over herself and outside reality for that.' And then there is the chilling collapse of Joe Chip at the start of Chapter 13, watched by an apparently unsympathetic Pat Conley.  I recommend those who have not yet experienced 'Ubik' to read it with an open mind and a preparedness to let the plot take you for a ride - whatever you do, don't try to make your 'solution' to the twists and turns as they unfold THE only possible resolution. Philip Dick will almost certainly take you another direction.    ******************************    other recommended reading:  John Clarke - Working with Monsters  Philip Dick - A Maze of Death  Philip Dick - A Scanner Darkly  Philip Dick - Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep?

B0009OPO0S|5.0|El pasado fin de semana fui a una actividad de la comunidad en el parque de Riverview en Melbourne, Florida, donde celebraban dieciseis anos del dia de la union racial (Racial Unity Day). En esa actividad participo un pequeno grupo colombiano bailando y cantando canciones folkloricas de su pais. En ese momento me resulto curioso saber que mi nueva asignacion, para el periodico local EL PLAYERO, seria escribir sobre la artista actual mas renombrada, talentosa y alumbrada de Columbia, SHAKIRA.<br /><br />Shakira la joven cantante, autora y productora nacida y criada en Baranquilla, Colombia, de padres de Lebanon y Colombia, acaba de lanzar un nuevo disco compacto en espanol, Fijacion Oral 1. Oral Fixation 2 sera su siguiente album discografico con temas en ingles que saldra a la venta en noviembre de este ano.<br /><br />El martes, 7 de junio, se lanzo el primer album, Fijacion Oral 1, el cual ya a roto records de venta mundialmente. El titulo del disco se refiere a la etapa de la vida en la cual el ser humano tiene mas fijacion oral. Esa es la primera face que es la mas elemental, instinctiva y primitiva. Shakira dice que se considera estar en esa etapa  ya que todavia esta en contacto con los aspectos mas animalisticos de su ser.<br /><br />Fijacion Oral-Volumen 1 consiste de diez canciones eclecticas escritas y producidas por Shakira. Algunos de sus colaboraciones son con el argentino Gustavo Cerati, que fue el solista de la banda de rock Soda Stereo, y el espanol Alejandro Sanz. Cerati canta dos temas con ella, `No' conteniendo buen sonido de guitara acustica y `Dia Especial'.<br /><br />Alejandro Sanz interpreta un duo con Shakira que ha sido un super exito. Ese es, por supuesto, `La Tortura'. La combinacion de sus voces es esquisita. La letra es directa y poetica ademas de expresiva, emotiva y seductora. La cancion es una combinacion de musica pop, flamenco, arabe y colombiana con influencia de reggaeton. `La Tortura' es basicamente un dialogo entre un hombre y una mujer y la pregunta obvia es quien tortura a quien?<br /><br />Algunas de mis canciones predilectas son las dos versiones de `La Pared' que contiene fraces fragiles y penosas. Una de las versiones es echa con sonido electronico y la otra mas intima con piano acustico. `Obtener un Si' tiene influencia de bossanova y jazz. `Dia de Enero' es una balada romantica y `Escondite Ingles' tiene un sonido punk rock. Lo mas interesante de estas grabaciones son las seleciones eclecticas y el uso de la poesia ademas de la musica del acordion. Me encanta como usa palabras artisticamente para expresar sentimientos y emociones.<br /><br />Tengo engravada en mi mente las lineas de la cancion `La Pared' que dice, \\"Despues de ti la pared. No me faltes nunca. Debajo el asfalto y mas abajo estar&iacute;a yo. Sin ti.\\" Y del coro de `La Tortura', \\"Ay amor me duele tanto. Me duele tanto. Que te fueras sin decir a donde. Ay amor, fue una tortura perderte.\\"<br /><br />Ademas de tener canciones excitantes y poeticas, el CD contiene un DVD del video `La Tortura' que es bien picante y sensual. Ah&iacute; vemos y sentimos la tortura. El DVD tambien incluye las letras de las canciones y dos cortos documentales. Uno es una entrevista divertida hecha por Alejandro Sanz que me resulto muy relajada, divertida y intima. El otro documental nos demuestra el aspecto creativo de Shakira haciendo sus grabaciones en su estudio de grabaciones en las Bahamas.<br /><br />Shakira es una mujer joven, inteligente, exitosa y exitante ademas de talentosa. Tengo mucha curiosidad de oir su proxima creacion o la continuacion de su Fijacion Oral 1 osea Oral Fixation 2 en noviembre. Sera esa mi tortura? Esperara hasta noviembre? Ay, me duele tanto, me duele tanto. Pero mientras tanto, continuare explorando mis trampas de luz por el camino que ando.n hombre y una mujer y la pregunta obvia es quien tortura a quien?  <br /> <br />Algunas de mis canciones predilectas son las dos versiones de `La Pared' que contiene fraces fragiles y penosas. Una de las versiones es echa con sonido electronico y la otra mas intima con piano acustico. `Obtener un Si' tiene influencia de bossanova y jazz. `Dia de Enero' es una balada romantica y `Escondite Ingles' tiene un sonido punk rock. Lo mas interesante de estas grabaciones son las seleciones eclecticas y el uso de la poesia ademas de la musica del acordion. Me encanta como usa palabras artisticamente para expresar sentimientos y emociones.  <br /> <br />Tengo engravada en mi mente las lineas de la cancion `La Pared' que dice, \\"Despues de ti la pared. No me faltes nunca. Debajo el asfalto y mas abajo estara yo. Sin ti.\\" Y del coro de `La Tortura', \\"Ay amor me duele tanto. Me duele tanto. Que te fueras sin decir a donde. 0792846443|5.0|MISERY is one of the best Stephen King adaptations captured on film.  Under the assured direction of Rob Reiner, the movie presents a chilling study of an obsessive...and deranged...fan.  Kathy Bates won an Oscar for her impeccable portrayal of Annie Wilkes, author Paul Sheldon's \\"number one fan.\\"  She rescues him after he has an accident in a fierce blizzard and nurses him back to health (she's an ex-nurse).  All goes well until Bates discovers that Sheldon has killed off her favorite character, the titular MISERY, and she goes bonkers and forces him to bring the character back.  While Bates is certainly riveting, James Caan is remarkable as well in his role as the victimized author.  It's a shame Oscar overlooked him for this role, as he is just as good as Ms. Bates, and gives a commanding performance.  Lauren Bacall, Richard Farnsworth and Frances Sternhagen are quite good in their small roles as well.  MISERY is a suspenseful and witty thriller, and stands as one of King's best.

B000660UN0|5.0|The weakest thing about Clapton's performances as a blues musician has always been his voice.  It's never been painful to hear, but it's definitely an Englishman's voice.  It made From the Cradle hard to enjoy - not because Clapton couldn't deliver the song, but because he sounded like it was work. <br /> <br />This recording has Clapton's best and most relaxed singing, ever.  Better than Behind the Sun, Journeyman or any of his studio recordings, a year of playing these songs since the Me and Mr. Johnson has done wonders for his pitch, phrasing and clarity of tone as a singer.  You already know how well he plays the guitar, and you already know he has the best damn band money can buy.  He positively swaggers through \\"Sweet Home Chicago\\" and \\"Stop Breaking Down,\\" and revisits \\"Ramblin' on my Mind\\" for the third time on record [first on Bluesbreakers and thereafter on Just One Night] to deliver his best rendition. <br /> <br />Also, all you self-impressed reviewers who think that this isn't sad enough to be the blues - GET OVER YOURSELVES.  The blues derives from the emotional experience of being black and poor, taking life's pleasures and pains in America.  Eric Clapton gives ample tribute to the more solemn, stripped-down feeling of the original Robert Johnson recordings in his duets with Doyle Bramhall, but then he turns around and rocks the house as Buddy Guy or Muddy Waters might have in the Fifties - when his idols were playing the songs of their idol Robert Johnson. <br /> <br />This isn't the only blues album anyone should own, and Eric Clapton's not the end of the blues.  But this album's a great place to hear these songs for the first time.

B0007Y08IS|5.0|I was slightly disappointed the first time I saw this film - probably because I was so hyped up about it, having heard so many people talk about how hilarious it was.  My second time through it, though, everything clicked.  Team America: World Police is juvenile and disgusting, yet sharply pointed satire that goes out of its way to be offensive - in other words, it's hilarious, and yet more proof of Trey Parker's genius.  Parker and Stone do things no one else would ever dream of doing - or even be allowed to do.  It's a film I know I know I will enjoy watching time and time again for years to come.<br /><br />Hilarity aside, the audacity of making such an elaborate film using puppets is almost mind-boggling.  Parker and Stone probably had little idea of what they were getting into, yet they stayed the course, brought together a tremendous team of individuals who, as the special features make obvious, relished the chance to take the art of puppetry to new heights, and created something that is really quite amazing.  It's uncanny how life-like these puppets are - I daresay Alec Baldwin, for example, is much more wooden in real life than is his puppet in this film.  These aren't just wooden characters dangling on strings; each puppet's head is filled with animatronics that control his/her expressions with uncanny precision.  The puppet fights are hilarious, but nothing's funnier than watching Gary give \\"the signal\\" as his first mission with the elite American fighting force goes south.<br /><br />As with everything Parker and Stone do, there's actually a point behind all of the humor.  Though their detractors would never admit it, these guys actually do have a handle on what is going on in the world - and within America.  If you've ever seen South Park, you know how quickly they manage to exploit the big issues of the day.  No one is safe from these guys' political humor, but the Left does tend to suffer the brunt of the satirical attack in this film.  (Those who say Parker and Stone are suddenly outright conservatives have obviously forgotten their short-lived series That's My Bush - which was the only unfunny thing they've ever done.)  Team America itself takes America's military might to obvious extremes, as when they pretty much destroy Paris in order to stop WMD-toting terrorists (of course, no one seems to consider the fact that the terrorists would have destroyed Paris to an even greater extent themselves had their plan succeeded).  Alec Baldwin's ilk, though, suffers most because they have two Stone/Parker targets on their back.  One, they are soporific liberals who would stop terrorism by sympathizing with the enemy and commiserating with their extreme anti-American views over tea and crumpets; two, they are actors and I think Parker and Stone really mean it when they say they hate actors - it's one of the reasons they chose to make this movie with puppets (plus, one of the original inspirations for the project was the idea of doing a parody of today's action films).<br /><br />I don't think I need to describe the movie, really.  Kim Jong-Il (even though he does sound a little too much like Eric Cartman, at times) is a great character, of course, but you probably know all about the film's story by now.  It is true that Parker and Stone push the envelope (actually, they just tear it all apart and rush right on past it) at times - especially in the puppet love scene and the vomiting scene - probably just to prove how much they can get away with, but you just have to expect that sort of thing from these guys.  It's one of the things that makes them Parker and Stone.  Let's not forget the songs, either.  From the heart-pumping theme song to Kim Jung-Il's loneliness lament, Team America World Police features a great soundtrack (be sure to go all the way through the final credits in order to hear a final little snippet from Kim Jung-Il).<br /><br />If you're easily offended, you'll probably be holding your nose higher and higher as you watch this film (even while those around you are bent over holding their stomachs with laughter) - but that's okay because the rest of us need someone to hold our popcorn while we struggle to regain our breath.her as you watch this film (even while those around you are bent over holding their stomachs with laughter) - but that's okay because the rest of us need someone to hold our popcorn while we struggle to regain our breath.
B000007T2Z|5.0|Sigur Rs has been described as the music God listens to. I'm entirely in agreement with that, but I'm sure it's referring only to the version of God in the New Testament, the forgiving one. Godspeed You! Black Emperor is what the terrifying, destruction-dealing Old Testament God listens to. And I'm willing to bet His preferred album is F#A#(oo), in which GY!BE have penned their most powerful and evocative music to date. <br /> <br />From the opening apocalyptic monologue intoned over a forboding bass drone in the Dead Flag Blues to the pounding madness of East Hastings up to the last surreal strains of Providence, GY!BE craft sounds so vibrantly original they almost seem alien. There has never been any group quite like Godspeed and there most likely never will be again. Get this album.
B00005JNJT|4.0|I heard such conflicting reports going into \\"Batman Begins\\" I really didn't know what to expect, but now that I've seen it I know how I feel: I like it. A lot. It's the best Batman to date (and I mean that in a dinner-and-a-movie kind of way).<br /><br />As you doubtless know pretty much everything we've seen from the Batman movies has been tossed out the window and this perhaps most powerful of comic book legends has been stripped to its core to tell the origins of the Dark Knight. Christian Bale takes over for George Clooney (!) as Bruce Wayne, drunken billionaire by day and terrifying avenger by night. I wouldn't dream of ruining the plot for those who have yet to see it, but I think it's safe to say that director/revisionary Christopher Nolan does a topnotch job reworking this story we've all heard a thousand times until it feels like something new.<br /><br />Not the least of his achievements is the cast, which boasts Bale at his best, Michael Caine as a kind and dignified Alfred, Gary Oldman as pre-Commissioner Gordon, and the always welcome Morgan Freeman doing a new twist on Lucius Fox. The real standout here, though, is Irish actor Cillian Murphy, playing Dr. Jonathan Crane, also known as The Scarecrow. I don't know if it's the cerulean eyes, the slightly off, I'm-hiding-my-natural-accent cadence, or the burlap sack, but he is absolutely riveting. (Although I doubt Nolan intended The Scarecrow to be hotter than Batman.)<br /><br />My problems with the movie are relatively few; I think it got a bit bogged down in the second-to-last half hour, and the resolution of Bruce's kinda relationship with the Assistant D.A. was lame. Katie Holmes has been getting smacked around for her performance, but I don't think it was so much her fault as it was the underwritten role. Had the best-friend aspect of her character been better written the whole movie would have gotten a lift.<br /><br />Still these are minor problems and Warner Brothers deserves a pat on the back for trusting their old war-horse to Nolan, who seems a little bit crazy. Then again, after \\"Batman and Robin\\", there was nothing left to lose.<br /><br />GRADE: B+/A-to Nolan, who seems a little bit crazy. Then again, after \\"Batman and Robin\\", there was nothing left to lose.    GRADE: B+/A-

B00005YXZH|5.0|\\"Yankee Hotel Foxtrot\\" was my first true introduction to Wilco, and I approached the band from the standpoint of an indie rock--not an alt-country--fan. I mention this right up front because I know it colors my feelings about \\"Yankee Hotel Foxtrot,\\" and even though I have since fallen in love with Wilco's previous albums (as well as other alt-country bands), all of Wilco's prior work seems like steps towards an ultimate goal: \\"Yankee Hotel Foxtrot.\\" <br /> <br />From the beginning, \\"Yankee Hotel Foxtrot\\" sets itself apart from Wilco's past albums--and from most other albums, period. The beautiful noise that introduces \\"I Am Trying to Break Your Heart\\" clearly has Jim O'Rourke's fingerprints all over it, and the album is better for O'Rourke's influence. Of course, the main innovative force at work is the band itself. Beyond the experiments with noise and music, Tweedy's lyrics have evolved as well. Tweedy's phrasing frequently sends shivers down my spine. Take, for example, this verse from \\"Ashes of American Flags:\\" <br /> <br />\\"I want a good life <br />With a nose for things <br />A fresh wind and bright sky  <br />To enjoy my suffering.\\" <br /> <br />And on paper, this line has only a fraction of the impact that Tweedy's beautiful, delicate and cracking, yet strong and emotion-laden voice provides all of his lyrics. <br /> <br />The songs flow quite seamlessly into one another, even though there are several changes of tone, from the quiet drift of \\"Radio Cure\\" to the upbeat pop-rock of \\"Heavy Metal Drummer\\" to the soaring journey of \\"Poor Places.\\" I find \\"Ashes of American Flags\\"--a beautifully introspective and searching song--and \\"Jesus, Etc.\\" to be the strongest songs on the album; the power of \\"Jesus, Etc.\\" is certainly augmented by world events that occurred after it was written. I don't think there are any true weak points on this album. I very rarely play \\"Kamera,\\" \\"War on War,\\" or \\"Reservations\\" by themselves, but at the same time, I have no desire to skipover them when I'm listening to the entire album.  <br /> <br />In short, \\"Yankee Hotel Foxtrot\\" is an amazing album both for its innovation and for the sheer beauty of its songs. I would recommend it without reservation to any Wilco or indie rock fan; alt-country fans who are looking for an introduction to Wilco might wish try an earlier album first.
B00001OH7P|5.0|If you just want one david bowie album or if you have a collection, you must have this cd. It was his second hit (after Hunky Dory, 1971) and made him a star through his invented alter ego, ziggy stardust (an androgynous alien come to earth to save rock n roll). Back in 72, he was a very ambitious guy, so when he heard from his friend, Marc Bolan of T Rex, that glam rock was doing well in america, he got to work.  <br /> <br />This album is probably one of his most unique ones (well, besides scary monsters, which is just very strange). All of the tracks have something different to them. My favorites are the first four, which are the soft and slow ones, and seven through ten, which are more upbeat and pure rock. As for rock n roll suicide, you would be better off getting the live version from ziggy stardust the motion picture, because (being the last ziggy performance) they took it up a notch and added some really nice backing vocals and you can hear how bowie is giving it his all. It's still a masterpiece of a song though. Overall, this is an album i can listen to all the way through--there isn't a flawed track on the cd. It was something so new at the time and it still delivers each time i listen to it. <br /> <br />\\"Just call me Ziggy.\\" -David Bowie, 1972
B0002858YS|4.0|The first time I heard \\"Hot Fuss,\\" I must admit I was more than a little scared to hear such blatant '80s influences--the 1980s was not exactly  my favorite era in music. After a few listens, however, I realized that The Killers were smart enough to take inspiration from only the best '80s New Wave bands, and keep these New Wave touches light enough to augment--not overpower--their own sound. \\"Hot Fuss\\" turned out to be one of the most exciting albums I'd heard all year. <br /> <br />True, I wouldn't call \\"Hot Fuss\\" a lyrical masterpiece, but what the album lacks in lyrical power, it more than makes up for in catchiness and pure rock power. The first single, \\"Somebody Told Me,\\" showcases this perfectly; it is a song that slides into your head and almost forces you to dance around. But I don't want to reduce The Killers to mere fluffy enjoyment; there are moments on the album that really hint at the band's possibilities. The Killer's strongest point is their ability to set such a strong mood in practically every song. \\"Andy, You're A Star\\" has an incredibly unique, almost sinister sound, and in \\"All These Things That I've Done,\\" you can sense the pull of change. Indeed, very few albums have made me *feel* the songs to such a degree. <br /> <br />I'd recommend \\"Hot Fuss\\" to most rock fans. If you enjoyed the singles you've heard, there is a good chance you'll enjoy--if not love--this album, since it is fairly consistent throughout. Ultimately, even though \\"Hot Fuss\\" may not be the most innovative or philosophical album of the year, and even though I tend to relentlessly search for deeper meaning, this album reminded me that sometimes it's nice to have fun and enjoy a record on a purely sensory level, and \\"Hot Fuss\\" is the perfect album in that regard.

0316168815|5.0|\\"The Lovely Bones\\" begins with the narrator, 14-year-old Susie Salmon, being brutally raped and murdered by one of her neighbors. This isn't an ordinary murder mystery/thriller, however. The story begins to unfold when Susie arrives in her version of heaven and keeps watch over her grieving family and friends.<br /><br />Alice Sebold does an amazing job detailing how Susie's death affected everyone around her. Her father, Jack, allows his grief to overcome him, while his wife Abigail seeks comfort in the arms of another man and eventually tries to build a completely new life for herself. Susie's sister Lindsey struggles as she attempts to create an identity for herself that is seperate from \\"the dead girl's sister.\\" Buckley, who is too young to fully understand what happened to his big sister Susie at the time, grows up feeling like he is competing for his father's affections with the memory of a sister he never really knew.<br /><br />Susie's friends also continue to grieve for her. Ray Singh, who was the first and only boy that Susie ever kissed, is never able to let go of the memory of his first love. His friend Ruth, who barely knew Susie in life, forms an uncanny bond with her after her death and eventually manages to give Susie the one thing she wants more than anything else.<br /><br />In the midst of all this grief and coping, there is also the aspect of a serial killer being on the loose. George Harvey was viewed by most as just an eccentric neighbor, but Jack Salmon suspects his involvement in his daughter's death almost from the very beginning. Not everyone else is convinced, however, and as the months following Susie's disappearance turn into years, the reader is left wondering if justice will ever be served and if Mr. Harvey will ever be caught.<br /><br />\\"The Lovely Bones\\" deals with a heartbreaking subject matter. I was hesitant to read this book because it's all about the death of a child, and I generally don't handle that sort of thing very well. However, even though I felt like sobbing with each passing page, it's an absolutely beautiful story about love, loss, life, and death. My review doesn't even begin to do it justice...just go out and buy the damn book! You'll be so glad that you did.well. However, even though I felt like sobbing with each passing page, it's an absolutely beautiful story about love, loss, life, and death. My review doesn't even begin to do it justice...just go out and buy the damn book! You'll be so glad that you did.

B00000DOXR|5.0|Ever since The Beatles released their groundbreaking 'White Album', the phenomenon of the double-LP has been an intriguing one. Some of these productions are replete with long-winded instumental performances, such as The Allman Brother's 'Eat a Peach', or the best selling double-live of all time, 'Frampton Comes Alive'. Others represent a true tour de force, such as The Rolling Stones' 'Exile On Main Street', or George Harrisons' 'All Things Must Pass'. Stephen Stills 1972 double-LP, 'Manassas', joins the stellar company of the latter category.  <br /> <br />This masterpiece of composition and performance rests on the diversity of Stills' musical influences. The album is loosely divided into 4 musical genres, yet the opening side, titled 'The Raven', ranges from hard rock to latin rock to powered blues to romantic ballad, and as such nearly defies being categorized. The songs in 'The Raven' are presented as a suite, akin to the opening sides of The Beatles 'Abbey Road', or much of The Who's 'Tommy', and the quality of the music holds its own in comparison with these other, much heralded accomplishments.  <br /> <br />Side two is titled 'The Wilderness', and features a decided country atmosphere. Side three is titled 'Consider', offering a bounty of gentle folk sounds with introspective, intimate lyrics. Side four is titled 'Rock & Roll Is Here To Stay', and as such requires no deep description. As Harrison would say, someone has given Stephen a wah-wah, and he hands it a grueling workout. <br /> <br />Each side of the album contains at least one song which would have to be considered a masterwork. On side one, the plaintive ballad 'Both of Us (Bound To Lose)' does everything but cry for you. On side two, perhaps the most alluring song Stills has ever recorded, 'So Begins the Task', finds center stage. The soft melencholy strains of the acoustic and steel guitars, and the tear-laden lyrics of this song course through the air like the wings of an angel. Side three opens with another plaintive folk song, originally written by Rick Roberts and Chris Hillman, but seriously overhauled by Stills, 'It Doesn't Matter'. And side four features the epic rock song, 'The Treasure'. <br /> <br />Interspersed are numbers representing the best Stills has ever produced in any vernacular. His hard rock leanings are indulged in 'Song of Love', 'Rock & Roll Crazies', 'Anyway', 'What To Do', and 'Right Now'. His blues prowess is delivered in 'Jet Set' and 'Blues Man'. Stills latino influences are given their due on 'Cuban Bluegrass', and he even offers an appealing, pioneering endeavor on the moog synthesizer in 'Move Around'. His acoustic folk skills are displayed on 'Colorado', 'Fallen Eagle', 'Johnny's Garden', 'Jesus Gave Love Away For Free', and 'How Far'. There is virtually no filler on either of these albums.  <br /> <br />Stills supporting cast deserve much acclaim for the opus that is 'Manassas'. Dallas Taylor (drums) and Calvin \\"Fuzzy\\" Samuels (bass) joined Stills in previous ventures with David Crosby and Graham Nash, and offer an able rhythm section. The real standouts backing Stills, however, are Joe Lala laying down a latin-tinged beat through a variety of percussion instruments, and Al Perkins offering scintillating steel guitar solos and background for songs such as 'Hide It So Deep' and 'The Treasure'. Chris Hillman rides along on rhythm guitar, and together with Perkins contributes haromonies that, at times, complement Stills gruff vocal delivery even better than Crosby or Nash ever did. <br /> <br />If there is to be a criticism of this production, it is that the performance of these songs, at times, feels a bit formulaic. Stills is known to be a perfectionist, and in the recording studio this may lead to a stunted feeling that was overcome when the band performed live. In 2000 Pioneer Artists released live studio performances by the band in their genesis. This video, titled 'Live At Musikladen', reveals how much more heartfelt and personal some of these songs can become, especially offerings such as 'It Doesn't Matter', 'Hide It So Deep', and even 'The Treasure'. Clearly, however, the complexity of mixing the stylings of a seven piece band and an occasional fiddler at times requires fiddling around a bit in the studio. <br /> <br />If you enjoy the more visible and commercial work Stills has offered in the past, such as 'Suite: Judy Blue Eyes' and 'Love the One You're With', do yourself a favor: purchase this CD and savor the true depth and breadth of a modern day troubador. <br /> <br /> <br />
B0007GAERG|5.0|This is as good as it gets for Mariah. I say buy it and be happy shes back for another run at the top of the charts.
B00005JNJT|5.0|Batman Begins is a cinematic triumph because it doesn't allow the power of Hollywood glitz, to get in the way of a compelling story that is character based and powerful. Bale is at the heart of that story - giving a portrayal of Batman that is at once - tortured and dark as well as warm and sensitive. The Batman franchise is back and in Bale, they have a powerful leading man.     Bale - a veteran of recent films portraying psychopaths, brings a psychopathic element to Batman : a presence that seems only slightly saner than the criminals he engages.      Bale's Batman has a lot of imperfections, keeping with director Nolan's vision of Bruce Wayne struggling to learn how to be a crimefighter for the first time. The husky whisper is somewhat heavy, admittedly. Batman struggles to hold on when leaping buildings for the first time. Bale feeling the pain of the flames when Dr Crane sets him on fire.     Nolan's portrayal of Gotham City also gives it a dimension that many of us can identify with. He shows us that the biggest threat to Gotham itself isn't supervillains but organised crime that infects and infiltrates all levels of city bureaucracy.     This Batman gives the franchise a soul and a superhero with human frailties both physical and emotional. Nolan and Goyer, along with Bale have succeeded beyond expectations in bringing respect to the franchise again. This is Batman at his darkest, most tortured self. This is the Batman that we have all come to see.

B00004SA86|5.0|This review is not from 2005, but from July 2nd 2014.<br /><br />This is the most successful and consistent collection of the Mahler symphonies by one single conductor.<br />In this review I will tell a little about my story with this set, give my opinion of each recording and suggest alternative purchases considering interpretation and sound quality. I am no native English speaker, so please forgive my writing errors.<br /><br />Even in his own time, Mahler's instrumentation was generally admired, although his music met little comprehension. Mahler tends to distribute the musical discourse among a lot of voices and individualize instruments in the orchestra. This makes it difficult to record him properly, even today.<br />This set has a good, but not excellent recording sound. One may imagine that state-of-the-art recording sound by default is much, much better. That is not the case, however. Sound quality differs, and sometimes recordings from the 1960ies can compare to modern recordings.<br />Kubelik tends to employ relatively brisk tempos and still keeping an incredible attention to details. This makes for demanding listening experiences. He has a good grasp of the musical architecture, too. But it can feel pretty intense some times!<br /><br />I bought this set as a budget option in 1993. I did not know anything about Kubelik as a Mahler interpreter then and had only one recording of a Mahler symphony, his 4th by Maazel. At a friend in Florence, far from my Oslo, I had listened to recordings of his 5th (by Sinopoli) and his 7th (don't remember which recording, but I adored it). And I had concert experiences with the 4th and the 7th, and knew Bernstein's recording of the 4th (the DGG).<br />About ten years ago I had the money and time to indulge in a Mahler collecting frenzy. It started by adding some other recordings of  my favourite symphony, the 7th. Then I collected about 15 recordings of the 5th, as I had never got warm with the Kubelik. It followed a crazycollecting of the 6th as well, a good deal of the 7th, and many of the 8th, some 9th, some 3rd, and even some more 4th and one single 2nd. I have only three recordings of Das Lied von der Erde, which is one of my favourites among the symphonies, no recording included in this set.<br />I have spent much time comparing the recordings, but probably not enough. Anyway, as all of us are different, I am still not so sure that you will benefit from my judgements. Taste differs! And as taste differs, please take reviews with a grain of salt, including this one, one cannot trust even professional reviews! Objectivity is not the point in art. And never take for granted that if you like one conductor in one Mahler-symphony, you will like him in the next.<br />Not having much time to spend in writing even in my holiday, I'm going to do this as fast as I can. I will only assess the quality of the interpretation/performance/recording, and only go to details when I really can compare. Now to each symphony:<br /><br />The 1st. Mahler's most funny symphony. I don't know many recordings, as I am fully content with the Kubelik here. Some claim his Audite-recording is even better. Better sound, but slower tempos, has Bernstein (the Wienna/DGG).<br /><br />The 2nd. Mahler as preacher and novelist. I don't know many recordings of this one either, as I am fully content with the Kubelik here, too. He is probably the most exciting here. Klemperer is good too, but I prefer Kubelik. Some times I listen to the slow movements by Levi, which sound fantastic, but I find Levi boring in the outer movements.<br /><br />The 3rd. Mahler's natural science-symphony. I have never been discontent with Kubelik here, so I searched only by curiosity, reading lots and lots of reviews, buying some recordings. A good sounding recording and pleasant interpretation is the old Bernstein (New York/Sony). For a while I believed that Chailly was even better than Kubelik, well, he is more catchy in the beginning of each movement, but often losing the spark later in the movement. So that judgement was due to zapping! Kubelik is better when it comes to building up. The reviewer Tony Duggan recommends the modern Bychkov, but I am not particularly impressed by that, although it sounds well. I stick to Kubelik. His Audite-recording is reportedly better than the present recording, but I am not going to spend more money on Mahler.<br /><br />The 4th. A child born from the 3rd symphony, a child pastorale, idyll, but there is a snake in the paradise. I was used to the warm and slow recording by Maazel before getting this Kubelik. One peculiar thing about this: I never listened through the slow Ruhevoll-movement by Maazel. Why? Because it gets boring, of course. But I believed the movement as such was boring, reportedly Mahler was never \\"consistent\\". Well, performed by Kubelik it is certainly not boring. Mahler reportedly calculated the timing of this movement to be about 15 minutes, that was Â«ruhevollÂ» (full of quietness) in his opinion. Kubelik takes it at 18'47\\", i.e. much slower than Mahler would, still it is one of the fastest on record and thus closest to Mahler's own timing-estimate on record. The movement is mostly played slower than 20 minutes. Maazel takes it at 22'31\\" â and that is not unusual even today. I guess Mahler never imagined that conductors would be tempted to take his music as slowly as they do in our era of recordings. Slowness makes for impressing sound, brisk tempos make the sound feel more lean.<br /> If you want impressive recording sound, the [[ASIN:B00000JCIP Levi Symphony 4 Songs of a Wayfarer]] is a good choice, although I don't like the mature voice of Frederica von Stade for the childish 4th movement song. Anyway, I sometimes listen to that nice-sounding recording. Sometimes I listen to Ziesak's youthful singing of the last movement, but I don't like the too high ambitions of her conductor, Gatti (overstating everything, I think). If you buy the thirdsymphony by Bernstein (Sony), his fourth (Sony) is a good addition; his soprano, Reri Grist, has at least an innocent voice.<br />Anyway, I think this Kubelik is \\"the best\\" of the recordings I know, and his wife, Elsie Morison is excellent in terms of voice and interpretation. But it has taken years to arrive to this conclusion.<br />Tony Duggan observes that Kubelik's brisk tempos don't imply glossing over details. Please keep that observation in mind for the next symphony:<br /><br />The 5th. Mahler as novelist, creating a story of a man, starting in tragedy but ending in bliss. Perhaps because I had listened to the Sinopoli-recording a few years before, I was not prepared for the way Kubelik handles this symphony. Only to a certain degree I agree with Tony Duggan's assessment, that the sound is to blame for the short-comings of this particular recording.<br />Returning to it, ten years after discarding it, and after experiences with more than 15 other recordings, I am stunned by all the qualities of Kubelik's account.<br />Kubelik was always superb with structure in Mahler, I have never been in doubt about that. Well, listening again is like a shock to me: I am stunned about the quality and attention to details in the recording that I eventually spurned, for reasons I don't understand anymore. For the sound quality, I tested the sound reproduction of the violin in the Tempo 1-part of the funeral march, and lo and behold, it is gloriously captured from 7'44\\" to 7'52\\", as good as I have only experienced with Barbirolli! And the Kubelik-recording has very clear rendering of the contrapuntal lines in all the movements. So I don't even have quibbles anymore about the sound, it is pleasant. Yes, a little more spacious sound ambience, a little more thundering brass, and it would easily be my favourite Mahler 5th, brimming with energy, sunny of course, I always felt it was, and a great sense of structure.<br />The reason for my headache ten years ago was probably due totoo much musical information in too little space. It can get pretty intense sometimes! I was like Madame Verdurin in Proust, who couldn't take Wagner; Kubelik's 5th was too demanding to me as a listener; I could not absorb its riches; it was too much!<br />But it might have been something about the sound ambience too, as I not even liked the relaxed rondo-finale.<br />So I went buying 15 other recordings of this symphony, only to return to it, finding out that after all it is the very best to my ears. The performance has not changed, but I. Mahler is not only about reading, performance, recording & mastering - it is also about the listener. Whoever has ears, let them hear.<br />The sound is surprisingly detailed but not spacious. With more spacious sound it would be the indisputable winner, only that art is no competition.<br /> If you want a recording with nice sound, I recommend the [[ASIN:B00008XS1R Haenchen]]. My review of that recording contains remarks on more than 15 other recordings too, including additional remarks on this one. Very well played and recorded is the [[ASIN:B0033BJSJ2 Barshai]], which many professional reviewers recommend. For my part I disagree with the tempo choices of Barshai, enjoying only the two first movements of that recording. But the sound is clear and yet pleasant. But my recommendation is and remains Haenchen for nice sound, but don't expect the intensity of Kubelik's sexy account.<br /><br />The 6th. Mahler's most classically shaped symphony is very much about struggle. No recording of this symphony has given me more pleasure than just this Kubelik. Yes, Kubelik goes fast, but I think it becomes the symphony. The fast marching rhythm of the 1st movement is not the real speed; the melody that unfolds is much slower than the rhythm accompanying it. I would have no problem with a much slower marching rhythm per se; the problem is that then the melody unfolds painfully slowly!<br /> I do like the almost similarly timed [[ASIN:B000025OPA Solti]] as well as the Kubelik, but the martial Solti doesn't have the same attention to detail as Kubelik, not the same palette of colours, not the same contrasts between conflict and idyll. Solti is more consistently rough, that consistence makes for a more easy listening, in fact.<br /> For really great sound with lots of details, and still possible interpretation, I have to use two alternative recordings: [[ASIN:B000001GBD Bernstein]] for the 1st movement and [[ASIN:B00005Y4NS Gielen]] for the finale. (You see, Bernstein DGG has a painfully slow finale, Gielen has a painfully slow 1st movement. Since both come in two CDs, you have to change CD on your player in any case.) But in the long run you don't lose many details by sticking to the Kubelik. (I have many recordings, even a rare Sanderling, yes, I have wasted a shameful amount of money on my curiosity: Bernstein DDG, Bernstein Sony, Karajan, Maazel, Abbado/Chicago, Abbado/Berlin, Levi, Neeme JÃ¤rvi, Chailly, Gielen, Tennstedt, Sanderling, Barbirolli, Bertini...) The fast and exciting Neeme JÃ¤rvi is hurrying over the so-called Alma-theme in beginning of the first movement, the same problem I have with the Levi, sorry folks, but I don't think his Alma theme stands out (is contrasted against the surrounding discorse as good as in Kubelik and many other recordings), and generally I don't get the colours, besides Levi also omits the repetition. Still Levi has spacious, modern sound! So I stick to Solti, Kubelik and for great sound I recommend a combination of BernsteinDDG (for the first movement) and Gielen (for the last movement).<br /><br />The 7th. Mahler's journey to the end of the night, both terrifying and amourous, not like CÃ©line's novel, of course. My absolute favourite symphony, not only of Mahler, but of all symphonies I know â and it was love at first listening, in Oslo Concert House about 25 years ago. I have always been satisfied with the Kubelik-version, but I believed it should be possibleto get more mystery out of it, so I added some other recordings. After a hiatus, I have returned to this Kubelik and it is currently the one I mostly listen to. (I don't think his second Nachtmusik is too fast, and it is much slower than the famous Kondrashin live-performance from 1979 in Amsterdam.) I have the Kubelik Audite-recording too, clearer, but not so warm sound.<br /> A very different recording I like a lot is the  [[ASIN:B000001GNE Abbado/Chicago]] (by all means, not his hazy Berlin), with great sense of mystery, as Tony Duggan observes; I happen to concur with Duggans understanding of this particular symphony. For the greatest sound quality, try the [[ASIN:B00005O7SS Gielen]], but in spite of normal timings, his interpretation is not on par with neither of the two Kubeliks nor the Abbado/Chicago, especially not the rondo finale. The Abbado/Chicago has some hilarious and some very ugly details. Bernstein (Sony) doesn't impress me particularly in this symphony, it is good, of course, but I usually stick to Kubelik, Abbado/Chicago and  â only for the recorded sound â the Gielen. I also do like the legendary Kondrashin.<br /><br />The 8th. Mahler's last blissful vision, great and demanding. This symphony is almost impossible to record decently, due to the multitude of forces involved. Considering interpretation and performance, Kubelik is excellent here.<br /> I also like the Bertini, which arguably sounds a little better. A wonderful interpretation and performance is the Abravanel from 1963, but the sound is somehow not fully satisfying; I don't know why I don't see the same colours. Not even Gielen has fully satisfying sound. For very detailed sound, you could try Wit. The problem is that not only his interpretation, but also his detailed sound is boring. The sound of the Wit-recording: Everything is covered, but nothing stands out and the punch of other recordings is missing. So what can I say? Best sound: a good concert hall.<br /><br />9th. I neverhad any qualms about this Kubelik-recording, but some people claim his Audite is better; it is perhaps more touching even not more dramatic. The problem with the perfect Audite-performance is the sound quality. It is a poor live recording of a concert in Tokyo.<br /> Best audio: probably [[ASIN:B0009I7OG6 Gielen]], which has incredibly great sound, oh, my, oh, my, what a sound! The problem is that Gielen doesn't touch me, only his fabulous sonorities do, and his 2nd movement goes too slowly to my taste. A compromise is the [[ASIN:B000063WRS Abbado/Berlin], with a warm, hazy sound, it captures sonorities quite well. Abbado however, takes the 2nd movement too fast! And although very good on sentimentality, he is missing a little in the drama department. When I am listening to the touching Kubelik/Audite, I am missing the incredibly good sound quality of the Gielen; while listening to the Gielen, I am missing the spiritual reading of Kubelik/Audite. I don't miss very much by the Abbado/Berlin, but I know it is not perfect.<br /><br />Das Lied von der Erde is not included in this box. My love for that work compares even to my love for the 7th. I don't think anybody needs more than Klemperer there. Modern sound, great interpretation and performance is the Bertini. Artistically it compares even to the Klemperer. (Kubelik/Audite is only my 3rd choice there.)

1594200106|4.0|Trap doors, creaky floors, disfigured faces of strangers appearing in the dark, and all the things that go bump in the night. And this is just the \\"horror\\" aspect of this deliciously implausible novel that weaves together the tales of old lovers, family tensions, and Barcelona against the backdrop of 1950's Spanish Civil War. Does it always make sense? Not really. Is it a bit overdramatic filled with grandiose themes that outgrow reality? Yeah, sure. But, just as the characters in the book celebrate the love of a good story, so must every good reader who wants a few hundred pages of escaping into another time, another place, if only for a short while.  Woven together with many moments of genuine wisdom, The Shadow of the Wind is an entertaining gem.
B000286RKW|5.0|\\"Goodfellas\\" is not only the best mob movie--it is one of the best movies ever made, period.<br /><br />Many movies show you a world you've never seen, a reality far from your own that nonetheless appears convincing and true. But few movies do what \\"Goodfellas\\" does. When you watch this, you feel more like a participant than an observer: actors speak to you, introducing themselves, talking as if they've taken you under their wing. You, the viewer, actually matter to them--they want you to like and accept and understand them, even as they do things that are unlikeable, unacceptable, and difficult to understand.<br /><br />The movie opens with a harrowing, horrifying scene: a bloody mob murder in a deserted wood, lit only by the red tail lights of a parked car. There are no clues as to motive or meaning; there is only pure, unadulterated brutality. Why, the viewer wonders, would anyone choose to live in a world so horrifying?<br /><br />Henry Hill, protagonist, narrator, and mob foot soldier, shows you why.<br /><br />After the jarring initial scene, the movie jumps back to his childhood, and Henry puts his arm around you and tells you a story. These men may seem cruel and immoral to you, the viewer, but to Henry they are gods. It's the ultimate childhood fantasy: they do what they want, talk to who they want, eat what they want, stay up as late as they want. No parents, no teachers, no cops, nobody to tell them \\"no.\\" It's a glamorous, flashy world, fast and loose, so far removed from the day-to-day grind of Henry's family that he's instantly drawn to it.<br /><br />For the first half of the movie, there's no reason to disagree with that judgment. Henry and his friends grow older but remain young, brash, immature, and beholden to no-one. And they face no consequences for their actions: a judicial slap on the wrist is the harshest punishment Henry ever faces, and even that is occasion for back-slapping and joking. It feels like paradise.<br /><br />Only mid-movie, when we see the lead-in to the initial murder, do we really understand what Henry already knows: this is a world where saying the wrong thing, making a flip comment while drunk at the bar, can get you killed.<br /><br />Henry and his friends continue in this lifestyle even as it eats them up, one by one. Near the end of the movie, Henry is a coked-up washout with no friends and no future, a paranoid equally afraid of police helicopters and burnt pasta sauce. The fantasy life he so lovingly constructed has fallen apart around him, has nearly killed him: objectively speaking, he should be glad to just be alive. Instead, he longs to return to the life. He misses the fun, the power, the glamour. \\"Everything we wanted was for the taking. And now, it's over,\\" he laments, and he's explained himself so convincingly and pulled you so completely into his life that you, too, understand and lament.<br /><br />This two-disc special edition further blurs the lines between fact and fiction by giving the real-life Henry Hill a chance to comment on the proceedings. The \\"Cop and Crook\\" commentary features Henry and Ed McDonald, the prosecutor who brought Henry down, observing and analyzing events. It's not a perfect commentary track--there are far too many pauses and dead spaces, and McDonald frequently has to prod Henry into talking--but it's fascinating (and even more so in light of Henry's subsequent arrest on drug charges); one senses that they almost regret the power of the movie, because so many people miss the point, seduced, like Henry, by the flash and the glamour. They also touch on events from the book not covered in the movie, like Henry's stint in the Army and his role in various basketball point-shaving scams. (The other track, featuring Scorsese, Ray Liotta, Lorraine Bracco, Paul Sorvino, cinematographer Michael Balhaus and editor Thelma Schoonmaker, is nothing super special. They spend most of their time talking about how the movie came to be made and how they turned a great book into a great movie, but they also seem somewhat awestruck, overwhelmed by their creation. They've captured lightning in a bottle, and they're at a loss to explain how they did it.) Still, people (like me) who already owned the previous DVD edition of the movie will probably find this new version worth buying, not only because of the \\"Cop and Criminal\\" track and the good-but-not-great documentaries, but (most importantly) because the DVD is no longer a \\"flipper\\" and you can now watch the movie from start to finish with no interruptions.<br /><br />Anyway, if you just want to observe mob life, buy \\"The Godfather\\" or \\"Donnie Brasco\\" or any number of other great movies. But if you really want to feel like you're living it, buy this; it is a great piece of cinema and an absolutely indispensable piece of crime literature. Before I saw it, I had a hard time understanding why anyone would want to be a gangster; afterwards, I had a hard time understanding why anyone wouldn't.ck, overwhelmed by their creation. They've captured lightning in a bottle, and they're at a loss to explain how they did it.) Still, people (like me) who already owned the previous DVD edition of the movie will probably find this new version worth buying, not only because of the \\"Cop and Criminal\\" track and the good-but-not-great documentaries, but (most importantly) because the DVD is no longer a \\"flipper\\" and you can now watch the movie from start to finish with no interruptions.    Anyway, if you just want to observe mob life, buy \\"The Godfather\\" or \\"Donnie Brasco\\" or any number of other great movies. But if you really want to feel like you're living it, buy this; it is a great piece of cinema and an absolutely indispensable piece of crime literature. Before I saw it, I had a hard time understanding why anyone would want to be a gangster; afterwards, I had a hard time understanding why anyone wouldn't.

B000063JDE|5.0|\\"Blue Velvet\\" was the first American film to fully explore the uncharted darkest regions of the subconcious mind, in the manner of European directors, like Bunuel and Fellini. No American director has broken open as much creative space as David Lynch, not even Robert Altman.<br /><br />\\"Blue Velvet\\" was the right film at the right time. In 1986, there was a growing backlash against the vacuous Hollywood blockbusters, as evidenced by the popularity of artistically ambitous films like Platoon, Hannah and Her Sisters, Salvador, A Room With A View, the Mission, and Children of A Lesser God. Movie goers hungered for more substantive films, and the pioneers of the art house megaplexes, like Landmark were anxious to corner the market those kinds of film. Bad news for your friendly neighborhood art house, good news for \\"Blue Velvet.\\"<br /><br />The fact that Lynch was able to bring his singular artistry to television, a few years later with \\"Twin Peaks\\" is a measure of the public demand for Lynch's provactive style of filmaking. The fact that his recent \\"Muholland Drive\\" was orginally shopped around as a pilot for a series and had no takers, not even cable stations, is a barometer of how times have changed over the past 4 or 5 years.  Decadence undermines the fabic of morality, and wierd movies send the wrong message about America, to people who need to get the \\"right\\" message.<br /><br />\\"Blue Velvet\\" stood further left of center than other the films of artistic merit,and went far enough out on the limb attract a devoted cult following. In 1986, if you were in film school, \\"Blue Velvet\\" became an artistic model of acheivement. Young directors aspired to make the next \\"Blue Velvet\\",not the next \\"E.T.\\" or \\"Jaws\\" as the previous generation had aspired to make.<br /><br />On the eve of the 20th anniversary of it's release date, critics and movie fans still hold the meaning of \\"Velvet Blue\\" as a sacred topic of discussion. It's influence is tremendous but it still retains the uncompromising edge of an anti-movie film.<br /><br />The film is resistant,nearly immune to all attempts to probe the nature of it's meaning. The film offers no apoligies for it's Baudelairian view of human nature. Debating the allegorical content of \\"Blue Velvet\\", seems to miss the entire point of David Lynch's artistic statement. Like Baudelaire, Lynch is at a loss to explain the brutal extremities of human behavior.<br /><br />Each time I watch \\"Blue Velvet\\", I uncover new layers of meaning in, the script, the motivation of the actors, the function of a prop, or even in a the use of an unconventional camera angle. The \\"Blue Velvet\\" I watch in 2005 is entirely different from the one I saw in the theater in 1986.<br /><br />The wooden nature of Kyle McLaughlin's acting only magnifies the volcanic nature and the primal appeal of Dennis Hopper's performance. Do you have the courage to really rip loose like Hopper? ...or do you hide in the closet,like Mr.Goody Two Shoes who peeps with lurid fascination at the performance? The rock star charisma of Hopper's wild man bulldozes Kyle McLaughlin's wholesome sex appeal straight into the closet where it belongs.<br /><br />The strength of \\"Blue Velvet is it's own inscrutability. Lynch's steadfast unfliching gaze at the most sinister impulses of humanity, is the metaphorical \\"gorilla in the living room\\" that nobody wants to talk about. Your reaction to \\"Blue Velvet\\" tells as much about yourself, as it tells you about the morality of the characters on the screen.<br /><br />As in all of his films, Lynch points out the contratdiction between the our high minded moral aspirations, and the predatory nature of our own behavior. The sunny small town innocence of \\"Blue Velvet\\" conceals a dark underworld of depravity that is governed by fear and violence. Our fascination with erotic nature of evil makes all of us willing particpants in the corruption of our own innocence. It's a message that stands at odds with own image of ourselvesas decent,god fearing people.<br /><br />Scrubby clean hands are capable of committing the most horrifying of deeds...just ask Lady Macbeth.  It's an unsettling proposition, but ambiguity has it's own reward.le of committing the most horrifying of deeds...just ask Lady Macbeth.  It's an unsettling proposition, but ambiguity has it's own reward.

B000002UB3|5.0|Though I'm sure every album ever released period has been hailed as the \\"best ever\\" by someone, Abbey Road beats out popular favorites such as Exile on Main Street, London Calling, Highway-Sixty One Revisited, the Beatles' own Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band, Born to Run, Back In Black, Led Zeppelin IV (a candidate for the most overrated album ever) and most certainly the snooze fest that is The Dark Side of the Moon. The only album that comes close is Coltrane's masterpiece A Love Supreme, but since that's a jazz album it's like comparing Martians and oranges.<br />Even most of the one-star reviewers (except for the ones who prefer the God-awful Limp Bizkit and Korn) will agree that George's Here Comes The Sun (the best song ever in my mind - then again, that title changes once a week for me, so I'm not to reliable there) and Something are the best songs on the album, which they are. Unfortunately, George was only allowed to write a small handful of good songs (two per album, for the most part) and he really shines here, delivering two of my three favorite Beatles tunes (the third being A Day in the Life). Not to discount everyone else, of course - the 16:28 Side Two Medley that runs from You Never Give Me Your Money to The End was Paul's defining moment as a Beatle, and was heavily influential on the prog-rock movement, for better or for worse. Elsewhere, John's Come Together and ethereal Because, as well as Paul's '50's rock homage Oh! Darling and hilarious ode to a serial killer Maxwell's Silver Hammer shine. Even Ringo finally turns in something worth listening to: the vaugely country-influenced Octopus' Garden maybe a kid's song, but like Yellow Submarine it's a damned good one. Even the overlong proto-metal experiment I Want You (She's So Heavy) holds my interest, at least through the first half.<br />The one-star reviewers quite clearly don't know what they're talking about. I mean, having different musical tastes is one thing, but believing that the Beatles are incapable of making good music simply because they're British is racist, and anyone who had any clue about anything would NOT say the Beatles should break up, simply because they did 36 years ago, leaving a gaping hole in the world of rock music. And Norwegian Wood was NOT the band's only hit (they have 27 #1's to their credit, two - Come Together and Something - from this album alone, and that's just the #1's), in fact it wasn't even a hit in the first place. I will agree it's a good song, though.<br />An easy five star, and rock's defining album.re incapable of making good music simply because they're British is racist, and anyone who had any clue about anything would NOT say the Beatles should break up, simply because they did 36 years ago, leaving a gaping hole in the world of rock music. And Norwegian Wood was NOT the band's only hit (they have 27 #1's to their credit, two - Come Together and Something - from this album alone, and that's just the #1's), in fact it wasn't even a hit in the first place. I will agree it's a good song, though.  An easy five star, and rock's defining album.

0151008787|5.0|In \\"A Tale of Love and Darkness\\"  the Israeli novelist and political essayist reflects on his childhood.  Oz tells of a morning writing the book in Arad, he is working on chapter 36, and says: \\"I don't know what can contribute to the progress of the story, because as yet I have no idea where this story wants to go, ....\\".   Certainly, Oz is  trying to understand and come to terms with his childhood, but I think his primary motivation may be even simpler: to better recall his youth and the people who were important to him, for Oz makes clear he does not have an exceptional memory, and that sometimes, like an archaeologist, he is recreating a memory from fragments (and whatever help he can get from other first person accounts of the time). <br /> What made reading this book such a memorable experience? Certainly, Oz is a talented writer.  It is unlikely that someone who is not a novelist could write prose as well, or recreate conversations and scenes as well.  Oz's childhood was eventful, and at least in his hands, his family life is interesting.  Oz offers a feel for a time and place (lower middle class life in Jerusalem in the years 1939-1948) as well as  fascinating stories about his ancestors, particularly on his mother's side.  What  really sets this book apart, however, is Oz's personality itself.  You have to love and admire this man - and enjoy his sense of humor. <br /> \\"A Tale of Love and Darkness\\" could have benefited from better editing.  I would advise the reader to keep in mind that Oz was born in 1939, for the book can be imprecise about  dating events, and some readers might wish to begin by looking at the family picture on p.509.   <br />

B00005JNNZ|5.0|My daughter came over to visit this weekend, and she suggested that we rent this film. Since it stars Samuel L. Jackson and is about a high school basketball coach, I thought that it sounded promising. Well, it turned to be more than just promising. It is a movie that held me riveted to the screen the entire time it was on. Samuel L. Jackson is simply outstanding in the role of a high school coach who sees basketball as the means to an end and not the end itself.<br /><br />Based upon a true story that took place in Richmond, California, it centers on a man named Ken Carter. He was asked by the retiring basketball coach of Richmond High School to return as a part-time basketball coach to the school from which Ken had graduated and left his mark many years earlier. The school is one of those schools in which people barely graduate and, of those that do, most do not go on to college. The basketball team was no great shakes either, having won only four games in the entire previous year.<br /><br />Finally, Carter is prevailed upon to take over as coach. He has, however, decided that he wants to make a difference. He starts off by letting the team know who is boss and by trying to instill discipline and respect. He wants to go back to fundamentals. He wants to put the emphasis  on being  a student athlete. To this end, he makes it clear just what his expectations are. He drafts a contract that those who wish to remain on the team, as well as their parent,  must sign. Some of the conditions are that  the players must attend class, do their schoolwork, and pass their classes. Those who signed the contract ended up making  the best move of their lives.<br /><br />Coach Carter keeps his side of the bargain, turning the team into a formidable one on the court. Suddenly, basketball at Richmond High School begins commanding attention. Notwithstanding this, he still emphasizes that they are to be just as committed to their studies. While one might expect some resistance from the student athletes to such a change, one would expect support from the educators themselves. What is amazing is the resistance that he experiences from the teaching community who are reluctant to give him progress reports on how his players were doing academically.<br /><br />When Coach Carter finally gets his long awaited progress reports and discovers that some of his student athletes are not holding up their end of the contract, all hell breaks loose. Even though they have had an undefeated season so far, he basically locks the gym and tells his players that there will be no more basketball, until he sees some academic improvement. To his surprise, the school board,  as well as the parents, does not support him in this matter, and the situation becomes a media sensation on the West Coast. Support comes from an unexpected source, the student athletes themselves.<br /><br />This is a heartwarming story about a coach who cared and dared to make a difference in the lives of kids that had little or no future. What he did for those students was incomparable, as he basically gave them a chance for a better life. Samuel L. Jackson is sensational as Coach Carter, dynamic and totally believable in the role. The young men who play his student athletes likewise give excellent performances. Ashanti also gives a surprisingly well nuanced performance as the girlfriend of one of the student athletes. Moreover, for those who enjoy great basketball, the on court scenes are extremely well done.<br /><br />At the end of the film, there is a summary of what happened to these young men. When the viewer sees what happened to them, the viewer cannot help  be but touched by the turn of events. Moreover, the DVD has a featurette on the real Coach Carter and the real student athletes for whom the appointment of Ken Carter was literally a life saving measure. This is a very well acted, deftly directed,  inspirational film and one that is worthy of being in one's personal collection.e student athletes to such a change, one would expect support from the educators themselves. What is amazing is the resistance that he experiences from the teaching community who are reluctant to give him progress reports on how his players were doing academically.<br /><br />When Coach Carter finally gets his long awaited progress reports and discovers that some of his student athletes are not holding up their end of the contract, all hell breaks loose. Even though they have had an undefeated season so far, he basically locks the gym and tells his players that there will be no more basketball, until he sees some academic improvement. To his surprise, the school board,  as well as the parents, does not support him in this matter, and the situation becomes a media sensation on the West Coast. Support comes from an unexpected source, the student athletes themselves.<br /><br />This is a heartwarming story about a coach who cared and dared to make a difference in the lives of kids that had little or no future. What he did for those students was incomparable, as he basically gave them a chance for a better life. Samuel L. Jackson is sensational as Coach Carter, dynamic and totally believable in the role. Elsewhere you get full length versions of Spirit and Medicine Bow that more than enhance the original releases.<br /><br />Add to the smorgasbord a number of terrific studio recorded instrumentals, some of which form the basis of completed songs that made the final released album.  There's also a live version of the title track recorded before the studio version and a number of other songs that in most cases were inexplicably left off the final running order.<br /><br />After a week with this, I've come to the conclusion that the extra CD beats the pants off the original...... and anyone who has lived with \\"This is the Sea\\" for two decades will find that hard to believe.
