0195067142|5.0|With the Old Breed started out as a chance for a grandfather to share with his children and grandchildren the experiences that he had during World War II in the Pacific theater. It ended up being one of the most gruesome, but also most realistic, documents on the war ever written. The detail captured in With the Old Breed by Eugene B. Sledge, is unmatched by any other author, and he should be commended on such a truthful accounting of his fighting as a United States Marine.<br /><br />He starts With the Old Breed at basic training where he enlists and then flunks out of officer school to get to the front lines quicker. In hindsight, one might think it was a bad decision, but the way officers where being picked off in the Pacific by Japanese gunmen, it might have been the better decision. Located in San Diego, his training allowed him to be taught by some of the best instructors in the United States, getting him ready for what lay ahead.<br /><br />His first stay in the Pacific was at Pavuvu, where he received more training specific to the Japanese, and was finally sent to Peleliu. Thinking it was going to be a fast battle like that of Tarawa, Sledge was quickly introduced to the horrors of island fighting that would characterize the War in the Pacific from then on. A month later, Sledge was a battle hardened veteran, surviving the front lines, reserves, etc. without an injury.<br /><br />It was then back to Pavuvu for some more training, work detail, and the much needed break from the front line. His next stop would be Okinawa, still considered the largest amphibious assault of World War II and the largest land, air, and sea battle in history. Sledge was one of the many troops circling the waters in an amtrac prior to the assault, and spent 3 months on the island fighting, delivering ammunition, and on work detail through the horrid rain and stench of dead bodies.<br /><br />Finally, with the dropping of the atomic bombs and the surrender of the Japanese on August 15, 1945, Sledge's journey through the horrors of the Pacific had finally come to an end.<br /><br />Sledge's account of the war is unlike anything I have ever read. He makes light of the stupidity, horror, stench, atrocities, jokes, hatred, and everything else in between. But he writes in a manner that is simple and easy to understand, without flowery language to smooth out the rough edges of war. And even though he experiences many atrocities at the hands of the Japanese and many stupidities at the hands of his US officers, Sledge still writes with an open mind, never pinning problems on one person or lumping together a group of people through his experiences only. He writes specifically stating throughout With the Old Breed that these are his experiences only and that they might not reign true for the rest of the soldiers. I respect that aspect of his document more than any other. Not really a problem but something to note when you begin reading this document: it was hard keeping track of where Sledge was positioned while on each island, but the maps of each area helped tremendously as references. I do have to warn readers that the book can get gruesome at points, but such is war and the truthful accounting of it.<br /><br />Some of the stories I enjoyed reading about include the basic training lesson about guns, the Marine who tried to crap at night, and the guy stuck between a rock and a hard place with his wife and Betty. I was horrified by the stories of the scavengers, especially the one trying to get a gold tooth with his kabar, the soldier who assisted a Japanese woman with her pain, the time when Sledge nearly had to dig a hole in a spot with a few too many maggots, and the slide down a wet and muddy hill that left many Marines vomiting.<br /><br />As I write this review, I can still feel the stress, smell the stench and imagine the utter horror of being on the front lines while the Japanese are bunkered up in the mountains and hills. Yet my imagination cannot even fathom half of what the Marines and other military personnel went through in the Pacific. I can only read about it. So I would like to thank those who went through this experience for me and the rest of the United States, because who knows what our future would have been like without you.<br /><br />To anyone considering reading this document (I call it that because of its validity to the War in the Pacific), do not hesitate to buy it and find it as part of your top shelf of books to read again. Everyone enjoy!y imagination cannot even fathom half of what the Marines and other military personnel went through in the Pacific. I can only read about it. So I would like to thank those who went through this experience for me and the rest of the United States, because who knows what our future would have been like without you. <br /> <br />To anyone considering reading this document (I call it that because of its validity to the War in the Pacific), do not hesitate to buy it and find it as part of your top shelf of books to read again. Everyone enjoy!

038533348X|4.0|I've just finished Cat's Cradle and I have walked away with a sense of low self-esteem.  I, however, will not allow this feeling to pain me that much.  Intuitively, I know this is a natural reaction many have had after reading Vonnegut for the first time. You see, after you have had your first experience with the man you gain an important insight.  The insight is simply this:  Vonnegut is more intelligent than you are and he revels in it; this, I am convinced, is what makes his writing outstanding.  The reasons for this correlation are easy to find for they lie, laughing up at you, strewn across the pages of this book.  On the surface, Cat's Cradle is a chronicle of the last days of humankind.  Its nameless protagonist, a writer, relates the tale of how he set the events that eventually led to our demise in motion.  His recounting makes our departure from this planet seem like an event in the best interests of everyone involved with the planet Earth.  For support, Cat's Cradle happens to rail against every absurdity present in modern day, western civilization.  All the things that make us suck as a collective are satirized brilliantly here folks: blindly ignorant nationalism, blindly conformist religion, and of course, politics.  In Cat's Cradle, Vonnegut has authored a book that has its finger on the pulse of the western human condition and I relate to and like it immensely.  For the first time, exemplified in this little novel, I can see all of the attributes that have made Vonnegut a champion to high school and college students for over forty years.  I am no longer a college student but I am more of a cynic now than ever before.  For those of us who can not turn a deaf ear to the discord around us, Vonnegut's writing will always be there, saying \\"It's okay.  I understand\\".

These are your typical broken love songs that QOTSA has been putting out since day one.   <br /> <br />All these songs are good, but they just don't click to the next level like Songs for the Deaf or Rated R.  Josh has proven he can make a quality rock record on his own terms, and it is definitely more polished that the previous QOTSA albums, but it's just not great.  It's good, but not great.   <br /> <br />So for fans of the band, this is a must have.  The songs are high quality and the album works as a whole. B0009HLDFU|5.0|Dave Grohl has had quite the career in music. Drums for nirvana, the debut foo fighters, on which he played and sang every note of music, the creation and maturing of the band, and perhaps one of the best and most underrated singer/songwriters around right now. He's the kind of person who'd be getting the \\"life time achievment award\\" if he created all these landmark moments for movies instead of music. All of these things show more than ever on the foo fighters fifth album, an ambitious two CD project. One CD is chalk full of the rockers that got the foo fighter famous in the first place, the second, a batch of acoustic and quiet tracks, in the tradition of the acoustic versions of songs like \\"Times like these\\" and \\"Everlong\\".     I am happy to announce that both CD's triumph. You'll hear Grohl scream full blast, louder than ever on the disc 1 opener \\"In Your Honor\\" and then hear him croon like never before on the disc 2 opener \\"Still\\". The difference is truly entrancing, because the foo fighters can pull off hard rockers, and acoustic ballads like almost no one else in the music industry. Most bands lean one way or another, while on this release Grohl and company lean both ways, and prove very good in both. Rockers like \\"No way back\\" and \\"Best of you\\" are classic foo material, and will bring back memories for fans of the earlier days of the bands career, while \\"Hell\\", \\"in your honor\\", and \\"The last song\\" deliver bone crushing hard rock, harder than anything the band has ever put out. It is however in this respect that \\"In Your Honor\\" shows its only flaws. Neither disc is strong enough to be its own album. The first disc is too hard, too loud, and exhausting, and the second disc is too soft at periods, and sometimes too boring. Both sides can't survive without the other. Throughout the first disc you'll be longing for the softer ballads, throughout the seconds, you'll long for faster, much harder music. I would have liked it better if they had been mixed up, split five hard and five soft on each disc, but its a small gripe seeing as there is so much good music here to enjoy.    \\"Best of You\\", \\"No way back\\", and \\"End over end\\" especially deliver addicting rockers that yearn for re-listens over and over again, while many songs on the second disc do the same. \\"Best of you\\" is one of my favorite songs so far this decade.     The second disc is really interesting to hear. Grohl shows how good a vocalist he can be, giving songs like \\"Miracle\\" a great feel. \\"On the mend\\" is brilliant, as is \\"Razor\\" and almost anything else on the disc. \\"Virginia Moon\\" is an interesting duet with Norah Jones, but its a little too slow, and seems to last much longer than needed. Its worth a few listens, but won't be a favorite.     By the time \\"End Over End\\" and \\"Razor\\" close out their respective discs, all complaints about Grohl and the band have been silenced, because they manage to pull off everything they try to do here. Both discs are excellent, and at the end of the day, despite my complaints, these are 20 of the best, most satisfying songs you'll find this year, and even if their presentation could have been better, this still ends up being the band's best album to date, and one of the best of 2005 so far.      (NOTE) I had no trouble uploading this onto iTunes.I just did what I do with every other CD, and I have had no problem with it in any CD players,but then again nothing ever opened when I inserted it into my computer...whats happened for everyone else?
0316172324|4.0|\\"Writing about Music is like dancing about architecture.\\"Laurie Anderson<br /><br />Instead of a phd thesis beating one dead horse after another, this is a book for those who 'get it' and get it right away. Whipping from one disparate topic to the next and then sinching them together beautifully doesn't make it a rip-off; it makes it readable, Not in a summer novel way. Readable like poetry that you want to take in again with a second read. For those who want a linear progression with detailed explanations, you won't like it. For those of you who find yourselves urging on your longwinded friends because you know what point they're getting at before they know it themselves, you'll love it. And those different thinkers are indeed, the very thesis of the book.<br /><br /> The style is no accident; the style is the point itself. Lovely, really. I read it in a sitting.
B00008F25Y|3.0|Dune, the desert world of Arrakis.  In short, the Dune saga was set in a distant future, when Man has extended his reach over countless worlds, and has plumbed the very limits of his own consciousness.  But man has not evolved past his own greed and lust for power.  The desert world of Dune would be a speck in the great imperia of Man were it not the only source of the Spice Melange, an otherworldy substance crucial to every aspect of man's interstellar reach.  In an age bereft of computers (they were outlawed in the aftermath of a now ancient religious crusade against thinking machines) only the sappho extract of Melange allows human beings called Mentats to think with mechanical precision.  Only \\"Spacing Guild Navigators\\" - human beings evolved over centuries of forced-addiction to the spice - can helm huge starships across vast tracts of space separating the human-colonized worlds of the universe.  Only the \\"Bene Gesserit\\" - a secretive society of women using Melange to enlarge their conciousness, the \\"Illuminati\\" of this age - can direct the warring aristocracy past each other's Byzantine plotting.  In a prosperous and chaotic universe, the spice is the beginning, the end, everything. <br /> <br />\\"Dune\\" couldn't be anything more than a major disappointment when it was first screened in '84.  The stakes were just too high.  Still, nobody was prepared for just how big a doff it could be.  Special effects are spotty, and the script is frustrated in trying to sketch a distant and complex era lacking Herbert's freedom to do as much in his novel.  Following the first book, \\"Dune\\" tells of the manipulated destinies of the Atreides and the Harkonnen - perpetually warring members of this futuristic aristocracy.  With Atreides growing too strong for his liking, the Emperor colludes with the Harkonnen to destroy them from within.  Unknown to him, the BG have plans of their own, to breed a super being who will rule the universe, and be ruled by them (eugenics being a BG preoccupation).  Unknown to them, Paul, heir to the Atreides dukedom, may be that super being - the \\"Kwisatz Haderach\\".  Unknown to Paul, the Spacing Guild seems already to suspect Paul's destiny - one that directly threatens their power.  Unknown to all of them is the role of the Fremen - the fiercely religious and independent inhabitants of Dune.  Manipulated by BG using religion, the Fremen have exceeded the furor hoped for by the Fremen, and ready themselves to launch a Jihad against those who would seek to rule their world.  On the burnt sands of Dune, where giant sandworms grasp the real power, and water is more precious than jewels, Atreides, Harkonnen, the Emperor and the Bene Gesserit collide to determine the fate of the universe. <br /> <br />So what went wrong?  A lot actually went right.  The disturbing eye of David Lynch proves scarily effective in capturing two critical aspects of the series - how its warring characters have become imprisoned by their own incessant and mortal plotting; and the pain the main characters endure as they expand their consciousnesses using the spice. <br /> <br />Unfortunately, what doesn't work overwhelms what does.  \\"Dune\\" is basically a biblical epic - set in a distant future rather than a distant past - but otherwise having the same types of characters, and the same widescale of storytelling in which individual characters get lost.  The special effects are nothing special (at least one shot looks more like a conceptual art piece for what the final shot was meant to look like), and the use of voice-overs seems to highlight an uneasy sense of narrative.  Characters just come and go, or exist just to appear instead of having anything to do with the story.  (Lynch perennial Jack Nance - Eraserhead, and the Man Who Found Laura Palmer Wrapped in Plastic, as Nefud, plays music as the Baron gloats.)  Still better than the more literal version aired on The Sci-Fi Channel, this version hints at the twin properties of both the Dune novels and the Melange itself - addictive and mind-blowing.

Many, like me, had wonderful experiences, but others were certain this was either a cult or an act of violent abuse.  We (both myself and my husband) feel our use of this technique has changed our relationships with our children -- they are both more bonded, more communicative, more confident in our relationships.  However, my concern for others is that there is seemingly a lack of a common sense approach to the technique -- it should be obvious to ALL parents that one does not put their body weight onto a small child, does not use FORCE to control a child's feelings, etc.  The technique described in the book -- stradle the parent's lap with child and hold the child's arms, then COMMUNICATE -- requires the ability to communicate EFFECTIVELY, age-appropriately to one's child.  This technique DOES work, though the author's claims of a cure-all are, in my opinion, a bit strong.  My advice to parents reading Holding Time -- if you find it isn't working, there is probably an error in your execution, so seek professional advice!

B00005K3OT|2.0|This movie had a lot of potential.  It has a fine cast, wonderful setting, and the beginnings of an intersting story.  However, I can't recommend this movie.  I actually found it irritating.  Here's why:    This movie has an agenda; a message it is trying to promote.  The message is a basic humanist take on life; be tolerant and accepting of other people, sit around and chat over a cup of hot chocolate and leave the larger concerns alone... if you do this you'll be a good person.      That message is not bad.  In fact, it's the underlying theme of a lot of literature.  The problem is that in Chocolat, it's so heavily pushed that it feels like watching a propaganda piece.  Over and over, the film tells you what to think and how to react.  It is as if the film were the very embodiment of its own antagonist, Reynaud... 'There is a right way to think and a wrong way to think.  See how we are showing you the right way?  This is the right way.  The other way is wrong.  Do you see how the other way is wrong?'    In order to promote its agenda the film tears down other points of view.  Indulgence is better than discipline.  Drifters are kinder and more intelligent than parishioners.  The Catholic church is first made to look lost, then laughable, then evil.  All is set aright, however, when the village priest sets aside more traditional views and embraces the main idea of the film.    Conveniently, the priest's new views are delivered in a concise sermon... and acutal sermon, caught on film so that we cannot possibly miss the message of the movie.    The bottom line on this topic is that the film believes its message is more important than its story and it really shows.    I also must admit that I found the characters to be very shallow.  All the main characters are either monotone or two-tone (my term for being initially opposed to the protagonist, then suddently changed to being on the side of the protagonist with no interviening struggle).  The protagonist is uninteresting (no inner conflict).  The Johnny Depp character is even more uninteresting (a drifter who is immediately accepted by and is accepting of the protagonist; he brings nothing to the story, except for being yet another outcast that is a good person and enjoys chocolate).  The only character that is at all interesting is the town Mayor, Reynaud.   But even the fine acting of Alfred Molina cannot save this film.     The film is meant to be somewhat of a whimsical, mystical, fairy tale, so I can accept some lack of character depth or true conflict.  Because of this and for the film's beautiful setting, I'm not reducing it to 1 star, but I can't give it any more than 2.

B00002DEGZ|5.0|So far, not one reviewer here rated this unique set of Mozart's grand concertos below a perfect 5 stars.  I think everyone got it right on this one.  This is marvelously performed music that has can transport you back in your mind to the 18th century Vienna of Mozart's time - the scenes we all remember from the movie Amadeus with the beautiful period attire & white wigs, old-world European buildings & concert halls and especially that tiny pianoforte that Mozart played so dashingly.  Playing an exact replica of this fortepiano, Malcom Bilson wonderfully captures this period spirit with these most intimate-sounding concertos. While not superceeding the staturesque cycles of these works (on modern instruments) of Perahia, Brendel, Schiff, Uchida and others, these period performance bring a fresh - even nostalgic - perspective to this most historic of Mozart's music.<br /><br />There is something about Mozart's piano music that is brought out with great charm and energy on period instruments.  As much as we can admire the grand sound and range of a modern Steinway, Bilson's fortepiano here, along with the period winds and strings, all combines to create a magical and inspiring journey back in time.  Mr. Bilsons summons a Mozart-like virtuosity in the bouncy allegros and rondos with his quicksilver, dancing legato and spirited cadenza runs (many his own).  The period winds are especially wonderful here with their more penetrating, darker sonorities creating a pallitable sense of drama.  The orchestration from the English Baroque Soloists is incredibly rich and most distinquished in these recordings.  They create a powerful, edge-of-your-seat drama in the great D-minor (K.466) and C-minor (K.491) concertos that is memorable.  An equally brilliant and truly exceptional performance is seen in the great C-major concerto, K.367 as well.<br /><br />However, in the slow, lyrical movements - like the poinant larghetto in the 27th concerto or the 21st's famous andante - Bilson'smodest fortepiano cannot quite achieve the depth of expression that comes easily with the wider dynamic resources of the modern piano. Yet, Mozart's charming and tender writing still are there, and Bilson makes the most of the moment artistically with equisitely-musical performances.  (It is no wonder that Mozart - being the lyrical songwriter he was - became so enthusiastic upon the development and potential offered of the sustaining pedel).<br /><br />The only aspect of these recordings that I wasn't completely happy about was the balance between the often soft-spoken fortepiano solos (which are sometimes hard to hear) versus the orchestra coming in at full forte (ff).  I was reaching for volume knob more than I cared to.  This is the only aspect that keeps me from more frequent listening of these recordings.  Gardiner comments in the liner notes as to why this was an authentic way to conduct and record these concertos, which he describes more as \\"grand symphonic works with piano obbligato.\\" Still, it will be a \\"show-stopper\\" for some which is unfortunate.<br /><br />Overall, this set is a real gem in the world of Mozart recordings that can give a fresh perspective on the great piano concertos, including many earlier concertos from No. 5 onward that not often included in the later \\"great concertos\\" collections.  An now-discontinued coupling of No.20/24 received a Penguin Rosette rating, which should give the prospective buyer some idea as to the high quality of the music here.  Overall, a splendid bargin (about half the price of other complete cycles) and treasure not to be missed by the ardent Mozart fan.  Compositions - 5 stars; Performance - 5 stars; Sound quality - 4 stars; Instrument balance - 2 stars.

B00005JNNZ|5.0|Ken Carter grew up in the tough ghetto of Richmond, California next door to Oakland.  He scrapped his way to most valuable player and record setter for points and assists at Richmond High School and earned a four-year scholarship in basketball to George Mason University in Virginia.  Twenty-eight years later he returns to his alma mater when an SOS is sent out by the veteran coach set to retire. <br /> <br />Carter is asked to return to Richmond and coach its basketball squad in this film adaptation of a true story.  The retiring coach is tired and seeking retirement.  Carter immediately sees the disarray the program has fallen into as players fight and curse one another after yet another losing game.  The team will compile a sorry 4-22 record, meaning that there is much work to be done. <br /> <br />Samuel L. Jackson, an Oscar Best Actor nominee for \\"Pulp Fiction,\\" turns in a brilliant effort as a coach who insists that his players seek to be the best human beings it is possible for them to become.  In this fast-paced Thomas Carter film, Jackson opens the first practice session by demanding respect.  There will be no more slurry, disrespectful comments and everybody will be called \\"Sir\\".  He then mandates that the players, who have been loafing in practice, work hard, sending them through long series' of tough back and forth running exercises called \\"suicides\\" and pushups.   <br /> <br />Once that the players get in shape and the meticulous Carter instills some solid offensive and defensive fundamentals in them they do the previously unthinkable.  The perennial doormat and laughing stock team begins garnering headlines by winning regularly, chalking up a winning streak of 17 in a row including one impressive tournament triumph. <br /> <br />The film then reaches its dramatic cornerstone.  Carter has insisted that in order to play all of his players must sign contracts to compile at least a 2.3 grade point average and go to class regularly.  When the progressive reports he has asked the teaching staff to compile are submitted he explodes, observing that his players have failed to keep their part of the bargain in the academics sphere. <br /> <br />It avails the players nothing when they protest that they have won 17 games in a row.  Carter brings the school's impressive winning streak to an end when they forfeit games and he padlocks the gymnasium, not allowing the team to practice or play games until they honor the contract with the coach by securing grades solid enough to enable them to enter college and become eligible for decent jobs and a good start in life. <br /> <br />At one point Carter is overruled by the school's higher ups, which instead opt for the easy route and ending the lockout.  After all, community pressure is strong and Carter is seen as a hard head, demanding too much at a time when the school is finally winning games. <br /> <br />The story takes an interesting turn when the players speak up.  One by one they begin to see that Carter is looking out for their best interests as human beings beyond the basketball court. <br /> <br />At a time when highly paid professional athletes have been resorting increasingly to spoiled and immature antics and the focus on winning has become in the eyes of many the only thing, this film comes as a breath of fresh air.  As sports commentator Bob Costas says in a brief segment playing himself, many Americans admire a man who insists that the term student athlete mean something, as Carter did.

Like I already said,this should serve good for someone who has been a fan of Def Leppard for many years now,and If You're a new or casual fan of Def Leppard and You want a taste of their music but You don't intend on buying all of their albums,then this should serve You just fine.

B00008CLOA|4.0|Everyone's entitled to an opinion of this reissue but the amount of misinformation in many of these reviews is ridiculous! A supposed recording engineer complains about the different \\"mix\\" on the stereo  track, when in fact the original 2 track tape was used for it. It's the SAME MIX, DUDE. He also listens to the CD layer and that convinces him he doesn't want to buy an SACD player. Now that's a blatantly ludicrous conclusion. Listen to the SACD layer and then decide if you want an SACD player. No doubt the tape has aged somewhat, which may have someone prefer an original CD, but the original Harvest UK LP still creams any digital edition of this record. However, the stereo master tape was used to produce a NEW vinyl edition that sounds better than any of the digital versions ever produced. And the Amazon reviewer who was surprised at how good DSOTM sounds considering that it was recorded before \\"digital recording techniques\\" needs to get a grip on reality. Digital preserves music the way formaldehyde preserves frogs: kill it and it lasts forever. Ask Neil Young. Or Wilco, or Steve Albini. Analog still rules. It's how we listen.......

The instrumental part in 'Powerslave' starts out slow with a soft bass/guitar solo but then explodes into one of the best guitar solos you will ever hear. Powerslave, and every other Maiden album with the exception of a few, is the epitome of what good music really is. If you don't own this album, do yourself a favor and purchase it know!

B000002H2H|5.0|This album, along with Master of Puppets, is Metallica at their peak. This album is one of the best thrash metal albums that is rivaled only by a few (Rust in Peace from Megadeth). The album starts out with a soft guitar piece that makes you wonder if you purchased the right album, but then the heaviness kicks in and off we go. 'Fight Fire with Fire' is a fast song with blistering guitar solos that tells about nuclear warfare. The pace is slowed down just a tad in the next track, 'Ride the Lightning', but it is still a killer track that has some of Dave Mustaine's cheesiness in it. The subject matter of this song is about the electric chair.'For Whom the Bell Tolls' is even a tad slower than 'Ride the Lightning' but like its predecessor, its still great. Next comes 'Fade to Black' wich in my opinion is the best track on the album. It's a slower track with a beautiful intro to the song and has some great instrumental work towards the end that neatly matches the subject matter of this song. Speaking of the subject matter of 'Fade to Black', don't ever listen to this song if your feeling suicidal. The pace is quickened once again in 'Trapped Under Ice'. I especially love the quick guitar solo before James starts singing. The next track, 'Escape', is the weakest track in the album, but as a testimony of how great this album is, 'Escape' is a great song. The following track, 'Creeping Death', is one of the highlights of the album with it's long solos and memorable opening guitar riffs. The album closes off with 'The Call of Ktulu' which is an excellent instrumental song that is on top with some of the best instrumental songs ever like 'Orion' and Maiden's 'Transylvania'. This album is indeed a classic metal album that is a must own. I definetaly feel that this album is better than the Black Album by a large margin. Purchase this album, you won't regret it.
B000268QB2|5.0|Tim Rice-Oxley's piano, Richard Hughes' drums and Tom Chaplin's smooth vocals blend beautifully to produce some of the most pleasant pop ballads to be found on one album.  In stark contrast to the swelling Coldplay anthems, it's hard to believe that an album could be this good without a single guitarist, but you never miss them here.<br /><br />Released over a year ago, the fact that it's still around speaks volumes about the quality of the music, and comparisons can be made to other late bloomers like Five for Fighting, Jason Mraz, Maroon 5 and Gavin DeGraw, who all took a while to settle in before finding their collective feet.<br /><br />All the songs are worth listening to, but the rapid repeats are \\"Somewhere Only We Know\\" the emotionally charged lead off song; \\"Everybody's Changing\\", a poignant cry about not fitting in; \\"Bend and Break\\" with it's soaring and unforgettable chorus; \\"Can't Stop Now\\"; and the grande finale \\"Bedshaped\\".<br /><br />The slower \\"We Might As Well Be Strangers\\" brings memories of an Air Supply ballad, as does the slow starting \\"This is the Last Time\\".<br /><br />Highly recommended to anyone who enjoys a great pop ballad.<br /><br />(Note: The import version has a bonus track \\"On a Day Like Today\\", but costs a lot more)<br /><br />Amanda Richards, July 5, 2005

B0009A1AS2|3.0|OK, now we're getting somewhere!  After the childish, 1000-note-per-second disaster that was Train of Thought, Dream Theater's new follow up is a breath of refreshing air.  They have returned to a more song-oriented format, yet still retaining the strong musicianship and progressive characteristics the 5 fellow from Long Island do so well.  It's a great pleasure to listen to a new Dream Theater recording that doesn't sound like a 70 minute long Mike Portnoy drum solo and an equally long John Petrucci guitar solo.  The restraint, mature approach and better leap toward songwriting forms from these fine musicians on this new release was well worth the wait.   <br /> <br />I find myself really enjoying some of the slower songs, such as 'The Answer Lies Within,' more than their typical heavy-bombastic numbers.  However, the CD still contains the usual Dream Theater fare with songs such as the aggressive 'Panick Attack' and the modern-sounding 'Never Enough.'  I noticed some reviewers complaining that there wasn't enough instrumental music on the record.  Though there isn't a full instrumental SONG, there's still plenty of musical ear candy throughout the CD (see the middle section of 'Sacrificed Sons').  For those who say Dream Theater has \\"abandoned all of their progressive routes,\\" don't believe it - that's hogwash and an exaggeration.  Interesting enough, some of the songs do, indeed, resemble the more common modern rock/metal sound such as bands like Muse which is an slightly unusual approach for the usual Masters of Prog.  Though some reviewers have panned that characteristic, I find their lean towards a modern rock/metal sound not only pleasurable but sensible.  After all, the idea of progressive music is to \\"PROGRESS\\" and not to stay exactly the same, correct?   <br /> <br />With all that being said, I'm still sticking with a 3-star rating because of a few reasons.  First off, in general, the song writing isn't stellar by any means.  Their move toward a song-oriented CD is a step in the right direction, but they still haven't hit their peak unfortunately, missing just slightly with a lack of strong memorable melodies and/or melodic chord structures.  2nd, I feel that this is not their best release lyrically either.  In fact, there are a few songs on this CD that I felt were very weak in the lyric department for Dream Theater's standards.  And lastly, for a band that broke out on the scene with great fervor and such a noticeable idenity, it seems that Dream Theater has wavered in the past few releases with who they really are.  I feel myself getting dizzy from CD to CD due to such exteme diversities.  Maybe it's their attempt to \\"progress\\" as mentioned above...or maybe it's just an illustration of a band who has lost a good chunk of identity.  Whatever it is, this is a  good step for them, but it may take yet another recording to reach their \\"superior\\" status.

B00011RPB0|4.0|Lost in Translation tells the story of two people, basically alone in a foreign-speaking country, who share a connection. Bill Murray did a great job of portraying a somewhat washed-up actor who is flying overseas to make commercials. Scarlett Johansson, a lonely newlywed with a busy husband, lounged around her hotel room in her underwear, looking out over the Tokyo skyline. The two happen to meet in the hotel bar, and they spend the week together, exploring the city and getting to know one another.<br /><br />This movie is not epic. It is a small movie. But it also very delicately addresses the subject of confluence, convergence. Adrift in a sea of people who look different from you, speak a different language from you, can you make a connection? Can you share something with someone? Sofia Coppola's answer is yes.<br /><br />This is Coppola's second feature-length work. (The Virgin Suicides was her first.) B0000009SY|5.0|Kids in high school don't read record reviews, they hear records in their friends' cars or in a messed up, smelly bedroom. That's how I heard Joe's Garage. This was a record addressed to  juvenile delinquents all over the world, because it very well captured everything you knew adults knew about the world, but wouldn't tell you. Sex, drugs, easy chicks, dumb guys, venereal disease, prison sex, prison, fascism and the \\"man\\" trying to put you down (ie. your high school principal). Adults trying to \\"review\\" a record like Joes Garage will never get the point because it was written to ridicule them. As a teenager, this record was a Godsend because the words were funny and true as hell, had lots of melodies we could all sing drinking beer and more, nasty guitar solos and had some astonishing musical ideas within it.<br /><br />Unlike most adults, Frank Zappa didn't talk down to kids or lie to them and he certainly didn't talk down to them musically. He knew that kids could understand and sing along to bizarre and complex musical presentations because their brains had not yet not rotted off and they were still capable of receiving new ideas and digesting them. So he relentlessly filled Joes Garage with them. There is some astonishingly complex, inventive music on these grooves. Who else was making  music anywhere like this in 1978? Frank Zappa actually treated his teenage listeners like living, thinking, growing human beings -- not dumb, amoeba-like automatons designed to be fed demographically targeted pablum to sell the maximum number of units.<br /><br />As a teenager, I was drawn to Act I much more than Acts II and III because the latter are much darker and mostly instrumental. Now as an adult I find Acts II and III much more attractive. Act I is party music, Act II is very weird and raunchy party music (which is what we craved as teenagers at 3 a.m. in a gravel pit) and Act III is just plain defiant and sad. This is music teenagers would like to make if they could make it because it goes through all the tribulations and is unrelenting in its honesty, its sadness and its funniness. In these records, Frank Zappa dropped a protective layer of cynicism and let it all hang out. That's why Acts II and III contain some of the best and most emotional playing he ever recorded. It's very obvious he put a lot of heart and weight into this stuff and he knew it was going to be severely trashed by every sad, balding, overweight 30+ \\"record reviewer\\" who heard it. But he didn't care. His instincts were right. I can't recommend these records to anyone because they weren't written for people who take advice from record reviews. For musicians or aspiring musicians, I recommend it extremely highly. A number of compositions and performances on this will rip out your short hairs. Peter Wolf's keyboard playing and Vinnie Colaiuta's drumming are standouts. The production and recording are beautifully done. Ike Willis' vocals are sublime yet insane (ie. Lucille and Why Does it Hurt When I Pee?). Frank's guitar solo on \\"Packard Goose\\" is probably the most intense and angry work-out I have ever heard. The songs \\"He Used to Cut the Grass\\" and \\"Outside Now\\" contain playing that is radically outside but not abrasive and remind me of the sad, elegaic playing of David Gilmour at Pink Floyd's most dark moments. \\"Yo Cats\\" and copy cats will never capture these emotions in instrumental playing because they are always smiling or frowning for the camera. The Joes Garage records contain some awfully direct and honest material which is why I still very much like them.<br /><br />
B0000A118M|5.0|Coltrane has long been emblematic for me in the best that jazz has to offer. A relentless searcher. Tireless dedication to craft. Most importantly, a desire to use jazz as a language to speak and to move as opposed to just entertainment or a vehicle to show dexterity or technique. \\"A Love Supreme\\" isn't what I would recommend to someone listening to Coltrane for the first time unless they're into some of the more passionate forms of jazz or want to see what 60s stuff sounds like. \\"Giant Steps\\" or \\"Coltrane's Sound\\" are more accessible entry points that feature ballads for those who are intimidated by Coltrane's cries. \\"A Love Supreme\\", though, for many, represents the essence of 'Trane. Raw, uninhibited. A man who has overcome heroin, practiced obsessively to capture for a moment his connection to the universe. Jimmy Garrison is highlighted here with some of his transitions between the movements on bass. The chanting in \\"acknowledgment\\" and the hymnlike final movement are what this album is best know for, but the middle movements are blues based and connect some of 'Trane's live extended blues performances like \\"Chasin' the Trane\\" on \\"Live at the Village Vanguard\\" to a spiritual expression.<br /><br />I love this album and listen to it often and I encourage you to do the same.<br /><br />10 stars!<br /><br />--SD
B0000009S3|5.0|I spent a lot of time listening to Hot Rats as a teenager trying to learn keyboards. Played it at 16 rpm to figure out the fast parts. The long stretches of instrumental improvisation were very intriguing because I had already heard a lot of live Jimi Hendrix on record. Hot Rats was similar, but different. Several of the melodies are quite complex and fast, and the horn harmonies can be quite dense. This was pretty dense stuff for a 16 year old but I really liked it in an innocent 16-year-old way and just kept playing the record over and over and it started to click. I still like it very much today. Like most of Frank's stuff, it's not easy listening music -- it definitely demands something from the listener. But, he does provide singable melodies and a good funky backbeat throughout so folks can have some guideposts as they probe deeper. Sugar Cane Harris' violin playing is excellent as are all the players contributions. Captain Beefheart's singing on Willie the Pimp (and the words) keep things from getting high brow and serious. So does Ian Underwood's sax entrance in Gumbo Variations. Ian was fully capable of playing a \\"sweet sound\\" but instead he plays a monstrously bent-reed series of notes meant to jar you out of complacency. I really like Frank's guitar playing on this. He uses a very dirty tone and technique. In places it's downright grubby. I like that.<br /><br />Given the compositions and the musicians he could easily have played in a mellow, polite and sophisticated \\"jazz guitar\\" style but he didn't. Instead he lets the guitar honk and make strange, raw noises that most producers would cringe at. If you listen to Johnny Guitar Watson's solo on \\"Three Hours Past Midnight\\" you'll understand the effect. I like Frank's guitar playing on this because he allowed himself the freedom to put edge and dirt into his playing as part of the composition, something he learned from a lot of the severely underappreciated blues and R&B guitar guys from the 1940s and 1950s. The guy was into contrasts. So what he did in Hot Rats is combine very talented musicians, some fairly detailed arrangements, complex horn charts and played some gut-bucket raunchy guitar over it. Some people don't like this combination, but I do. A very nice record that will challenge folks, be an inspiration to some, and be liked by many for a long time.

0767802470|5.0|This film is brilliant in virtually every way. It's certainly the most authentic sea war movie ever made. The claustrophobic sets and direction truly take you for a U-boat ride and let you experience the sheer terror of depth bombs and other dangers. The english dubbing is extraordinarily well done; but watching the film with dubbing makes you lose just a bit of dialogue from the film's original German language. The Director's Cut DVD features English and German Dolby 5.1 soundtracks, as well as a Spanish and English 2.0 Dolby Surround track. There's also a commentary track featuring the director of the film (Wolfgang Peterson), actor J&uuml;rgen Prochnow and producer Ortwin Freyermuth. Also, if you prefer to watch the film in it's original German language, the disc features English, Spanish, and French subtitles. Although the original aspect ratio is 1.66:1, the transfer on the Director's Cut DVD was done at 1.85:1. It is a beautiful anamorphic transfer with excellent sound. Das Boot is an extraordinary film, and definitely the greatest submarine film ever made.
B0000DD7LC|4.0|The Diary of Alicia Keys is easily one of the best neo-soul  albums you may ever hear. Like \\"Fallin\\" from the Songs in A Minor album, its climactic, her piano play is unparalled, and her voice is perfect. Also, like her freshman LP, each of The Diary's songs have their own personality, and stirs up various emotions. \\"Karma\\" has the sound of a fed woman who's had enough from her man, while \\"Dragon Days\\" paints the picture of a woman in need of some affection.    Though this album isn't as good as the first, its still one of the best albums ever made. Alicia's ability to experiment with new sounds, her soulful voice, and her play on the piano has made her one of the most unique artists ever.

It stays away from the Land of Predictability, the plot twists were believable and the end was a stunner. Trust me, not your typical ending. And the music selection was also impressive, it gave the movie that extra feel. <br /> <br />In short, I really liked this movie. It's not groundbreaking, but it does stand out. I have since watched this movie at least 5 times, and never tire of it. Definitely recommended!

Colin Farrell, LL Cool J and Michelle Rodriguez are the actors who make up part of that team.<br /><br />The creators of \\"S.W.A.T.\\" have done a pretty decent job given the limitations of the genre.  It's true that the plot is standard issue stuff for the most part and the characters have little opportunity to distinguish themselves and develop.  However, the dialogue is frequently crackling and the performers go through the motions with seriousness and conviction.  The action scenes are also well handled, even if they do go a bit overboard from time to time, a problem endemic to virtually all action films these days, not just this one.<br /><br />Chances are you probably won't remember a thing about \\"S.W.A.T.\\" much past its closing credits, but it's a fun enough ride while you`re watching it.

B00005JN2Z|3.0|One of the major problems I have with many action movies is that they seemingly attempt to suspend your logic to the point of insulting your intelligence-it really gets to be like a proverbial slap in the face after awhile. This movie, like many of its predecessors, follows some of the action film clich's: ordinary guy getting involved in an event over his head, somehow protagonist must save girl from danger, big car chases where many red lights are run and luckily no innocent citizens are run over, explosions, sharpshooters that somehow miss easy targets but hit difficult ones, the over-drawn chase and fight scenes, etc. For what it is worth, this is an entertaining film. It certainly held my interest for the most part, but it began to wane as the movie progressed. I found the first half of the movie was far more enjoyable than the latter half, and, as the second half unfolded, and with each new chase and each new murder by Cruise, I found myself rolling my eyes more and more at the preposterousness of it all. <br /> <br />For instance, are we actually to believe that sharpshooters from the LAPD and FBI units, as well as security guards are all going to fail to hit Vincent (Cruise's character) in the nightclub?  Equally implausible is the dancing that continues to go on as weapons are drawn, shots are fired, and commands such as \\"Put your hands in the air\\" and \\"This is the FBI\\" are being screamed at the club. Some liken Tom Cruise to a human, malevolent Terminator in this movie, and in this segment he plays out this machine-like quality to perfection, as he stoically and unemotionally beats down innocent by-standers and, well, calmly shoots innocent by-standers that happen to be anywhere near Max (Jamie Foxx).  <br /> <br />Perhaps a bigger illusion is the ridiculously implausible ending. I don't want to give too much away, but let's just say it involves a car crash, a woman alone in a building, a chase, and two injured people with guns aboard a subway. It reallyis a let down when a movie tries to go so far over-the-top at the climax and conclusion, and Mann (director) does so at the point after the taxi crash to the extent where many of the \\"positives\\" of the movie are easily forgotten.  <br /> <br />Still, on a lighter note, an aspect of the movie that is rewarding is the acting in itself. Tom Cruise plays his rare role as a bad guy, a hit man, to perfection, and Jamie Foxx does an equally commendable job playing the easy-going cab driver with bigger goals in life. They seem to know their characters well, and it is Max, Foxx's character that shifts from the early part of the movie to the latter part. However, one problem about Foxx's character that was slightly an annoyance was the occasional muttering and mumbling that made his lines indiscernible.  <br /> <br />Overall, it was a decent film, but nothing meriting the 5 stars. It is a fun movie and it will be better if you can stretch your imagination and not be bothered by the usual clichs in action films.  <br />
0316776963|5.0|Sedaris, if you have not read him, is more than worth your while.<br />Very, very, very funny. Very real, very poignant. Somewhat this is the story of his life as kind of a gay Everyman- an alternately-oriented Charlie Brown if you will. The orientation issue is never overpowering, more woven in as it is added to the list of things that life has thrown at him that he must make the best of. The family is dysfunctional, but with a lot of character and even love, and keeps the stories from just being about a sad, rootless soul. The encounters with the machinery of southern public school, northern private commerce (as a pre-Will Farrel elf), and with France are exquisite. His life is one that we can identify with, maybe with a substitution here or there. His observational humor is clever, and his classic self-deprecating wit helps the reader to always want to root for him. There aren't, and I guess never have been, a lot of great humor writers out there (once you get past the Simpson's writers), but to me Sedaris can take his place with the best of them. I'm pretty conservative, but I know a good laugh when I see one, and a good book when I read one, and this is a very, very good book.

B0007VZ9DK|4.0|Casino was Martin Scorsese's first attempt at a big budget, studio-backed epic. He would take the style and structure of GoodFellas and expand it on a much more ambitious level. Many criticized Casino as GoodFellas Part 2 but this is merely a superficial reading of Scorsese's movie. Casino completes his unofficial trilogy of gangster films. Mean Streets  is all about small-time, street-level hoods, GoodFellas is about mid-level crooks who wield more power and Casino is about the big time: gangsters who run large casinos that generate millions of dollars. With this film, Scorsese not only shows us how Las Vegas casinos were run by East Coast wise guys but the rise and fall of one man whose ambition overtook his grasp and his blind love of a woman that ultimately resulted in his downfall.<br /><br />Scorsese's film examines the notion of Las Vegas as being some sort of perverse paradise on Earth, a place where there were no limits. To this end, Casino features a vibrant, often garish colour scheme; loud, wall-to-wall music; and all sorts of excesses that illustrate the decadent nature of Las Vegas and how the characters in the film are consumed completely by it. Ace, Ginger and Nicky have too much money and are drunk on power. Ace deludes himself into thinking that he can always stay in control. He creates a false sense of security, believing that he could lead a normal life in Las Vegas<br /><br />Casino documents a bygone era that no longer exists. Now, Las Vegas has been taken over by corporations and become a theme park for the whole family. The film examines Las Vegas during its heyday when it was strictly a playground for adults.<br /><br />The first DVD features an audio commentary by Martin Scorsese, co-screenwriter Nicholas Pileggi, editor Thelma Schoonmaker and others. This track is done in the style of a Criterion commentary with several participants edited together to eliminate dead air and provide multiple viewpoints... only not as good. As they did on the GoodFellas commentary, Pileggi and Scorsese dominate and talk about the film's themes in a very eloquent and engaging way.<br /><br />The second DVD starts off with an eight minute featurette entitled, \\"Casino: The Story.\\" There is quite a bit of overlap from the commentary track on this and the other featurettes.<br /><br />\\"Casino: The Cast and Characters\\" is a substantial look at the actors and the characters they played. While De Niro and Pesci appear in interviews done during the film's release, Stone contributes a brand new one and speaks candidly about how hard she campaigned for the role of Ginger. As she recounts her experiences of working on the movie, she is actually moved to tears in a very revealing moment.<br /><br />\\"Casino: The Look\\" examines how the period detail was achieved by production designer Dante Ferretti. Scorsese actually shot in Vegas casinos and talks briefly about the challenges of shooting in such a busy, noisy environment.<br /><br />\\"Casino: After the Filming\\" takes a look at the editing process. Schoonmaker talks about how Scorsese had already thought out the visuals and even some of the editing before shooting the movie.<br /><br />There are three minutes of deleted scenes that resemble outtakes more than anything else. There is a funny take with Scorsese's mom and Pesci goofing around on the set.<br /><br />\\"Vegas and the Mob\\" takes a look at the real life gangsters that the film is based on. It traces the rise of the Mob-run casinos in the `30s with Bugsy Siegel, to their demise in the `70s.<br /><br />One of the most substantial extras is a History Channel documentary about Frank \\"Lefty\\" Rosenthal. This is an informative, fact-based contrast to the stylish, fictionalized version in Casino.<br /><br />Finally, there are production notes.on the GoodFellas commentary, Pileggi and Scorsese dominate and talk about the film's themes in a very eloquent and engaging way. <br /> <br />The second DVD starts off with an eight minute featurette entitled, \\"Casino: The Story.\\" There is quite a bit of overlap from the commentary track on this and the other featurettes. <br /> <br />\\"Casino: The Cast and Characters\\" is a substantial look at the actors and the characters they played. While De Niro and Pesci appear in interviews done during the film's release, Stone contributes a brand new one and speaks candidly about how hard she campaigned for the role of Ginger. As she recounts her experiences of working on the movie, she is actually moved to tears in a very revealing moment. <br /> <br />\\"Casino: The Look\\" examines how the period detail was achieved by production designer Dante Ferretti. Scorsese actually shot in Vegas casinos and talks briefly about the challenges of shooting in such a busy, noisy environment. <br /> <br />\\"Casino: After the Filming\\" takes a look at the editing process. Schoonmaker talks about how Scorsese had already thought out the visuals and even some of the editing before shooting the movie. <br /> <br />There are three minutes of deleted scenes that resemble outtakes more than anything else. There is a funny take with Scorsese's mom and Pesci goofing around on the set. <br /> <br />\\"Vegas and the Mob\\" takes a look at the real life gangsters that the film is based on. B0002WS3RS|5.0|Like most of Gong's albums, this has been released on CD a number of times.  The CD's have varying sound quality. They weren't horrible, but they weren't great. This remaster has excellent, beautiful sound.  It really brings out the atmosphere of the music. <br /> <br />The original album was 45 minutes long.  15 minutes of extra tracks have been added, bringing the CD to just under 60 minutes.  I don't think that any of the bonus tracks are all that great.  They aren't bad, they just don't make it worth buying this if you already have an older copy. <br /> <br />This remaster has a nice 8 page booklet, containing the lyrics and all the info on Gong and the Pot Head Pixies.  The only thing missing is the blue artwork that was on the inside of the gatefold of the original LP cover. <br /> <br />This is just another great Gong album.  It has some of the spaciest and wildest music of any of the Gong albums.  It also has a number of great songs.  While it is very spacy, it is also very coherent and holds together well.  The only downside is that there are a few short silly songs.   <br /> <br />This album is as good as You, but somewhat different.  There are more songs, and they are a bit shorter than what is on You. <br /> <br />Gong released 3 albums in the 1970's dealing with Radio Gnome Invisible and the Pothead Pixies (Flying Teapot, Angel's Egg and You).  In all, Gong released 5 to 7 albums in the 1970's (depending on how you are counting) before splintering.  The leader of the band, Daevid Allen left, and the remainder became a jazz fusion band. <br /> <br />Throught the eighties, Allen would reform the space version of Gong, and the jazz version got renamed Pierrie Moerlen's Gong.  The jazz band disbanded in the eighties.  <br /> <br />Allen reformed Gong permanently in the late nineties, and the band has put out a number of studio and live albums.  They are all very good.  The last three studio albums have carried on the story of the Pot Head Pixies.

B00005ASHM|4.0|The Beach Boys said it time and again: That The Beatles were their inspiration to keep writing good songs and produce better music (if only such competition existed in today's sick joke of a music market...) and Pet Sounds was inspired by, in my opinion, The Boys' best album, Rubber Soul (a record that wasn't heavy on the studio tricks as its close second, Revolver, was).<br /><br />America was, by 1966, still searching for a homegrown answer to top the boys from Britain, and Pet Sounds was supposed to be it.  A group that made its mark on the charts by singing about the beach and how superior one state's women (probably, again, from the beach) were to women from the rest of the country were supposed to be the answer.  I don't think so.  (Yeah, yeah, The Beatles sung about teenybopper love in the beginning of their careers but they progressed quite nicely.)<br /><br />I listened to Pet Sounds quite a few times with an open mind and the only three songs I wound up liking were the ones I liked before: Wouldn't It Be Nice, Sloop John B, and God Only Knows (which Paul McCartney, I believe, called one of the prettiest songs he ever heard).  It didn't grow on me and I wish I could have liked it more.<br /><br />I don't take away Brian Wilson's producing capabilities but The Beatles they were not nor could ever be.

0671027344|5.0|This is a FANTASTIC book! I read it simply because I was intrigued by the title, having been referred to as a \\"wallflower\\" myself. Although it has been compared to J.D. Salinger's Catcher in the Rye, I think it has a much more structured storyline and easier plot to follow. If anything I think it could be compared to the more modern book, You Don't Know Me (another book I highly recommend). Written through a series of letters to the person who \\"didn't sleep with that person at the party even though they could have\\", it opens a window into the main character's life that gives a view that is more personal than anything else I have read so far.  <br /> <br />The main character, Charley, struggles to discover who he is and who he can trust in a world where it seems like no one can be trusted and no one is who they appear to be. Living life on the sidelines, Charley notices things about human nature that most of us just brush off. He becomes very sensitive to little things (and, I will admit, he cries an awful lot). Upon seeing his talent for writing and understanding literature and his tendency to pull away from groups, Charley's advanced English teacher befriends him and encourages him to get involved so that he doesn't spend life on the sidelines for so long that he forgets to live. Because of his teacher's advice, Charley meets his two best friends, Patrick (a homosexual senior) and Sam (the love of his life).  <br /> <br />The book follows Charley through his first year of high school where he encounters drinking, drugs (of all sorts), rape, sexual abuse, physical abuse, abortion, suicide, homosexuality, masturbation, and the value of friends and family. It's a touching novel that shows the darker qualities of human life and looks at the parts of a person's character that is so often hidden. Whether or not you can relate to the main character makes no difference. Wallflower is a novel that will excite, invigorate, and capture readers of all ages and will reach out to all teens in a way that most of us never thought possible. <br />

B00097DX3U|2.0|To begin with, I LOVE AUDIOSLAVE!  One of the best live rock bands of the new millenium, as far as I'm concerned.  With that said, I WANT so badly to like this album, but it just seems like my standards have surpassed myself in that regard.    Maybe my expectations were just a tad too high?  Their debut was decent, but nothing amazing (even though there are GREAT songs like, \\"Set It Off\\", \\"Like A Stone\\", \\"Who You Are\\", and \\"I Am the Highway\\").  I figured it was reasonable for their first cd to come off a bit shaky, seeing as how they had very little time to gel as a cohesive unit.  I figured after having been on the road together, they would become tighter as a band, and in a position to feel free to let their best ideas yet come flowing through...    Well, then what happened?  Maybe Rick Rubin was just too busy with his other projects that year (Weezer, System of a Down, Shakira).  Had he been paying more attention to Audioslave in pre-production, he never would've allowed Tom Morello to recycle the riff from \\"Cochise\\", and try to pass it off as a new song.  I have no problem with there being softer songs on the cd, but if a song is going to be mellow, it needs to be EXCITING; to keep the listener's attention (listen to The Beatles or Pink Floyd for some of the most exciting soft-rockers ever), there should be a strong hook to help carry the song.  Chris Cornell has a great voice, but there needs to be a definitive, memorable, melody that people can latch on to.      Another problem that I had with the last album that I noticed is still a problem on this cd:  there needs to be more diversity in the rhythym section.  Almost EVERY song is mid-tempo, 4/4 time signature.  I was hoping they would break out of their comfort zone a little bit, but those moments were sparse, if present at all.  I'm all for simplistic and funky, but there's about a million and a half ways to bring the funk, if only Brad and Tim would take notice.    I do however, love the single, \\"Be Yourself\\".  It's one of the few moments on the cd that doesn't feel contrived, it has a great melody, and it's memorable.  The guitar solo from \\"Man or Animal\\" was quite exciting also, and helped bring my rating up one star as well.    Overall though, the album is very predictable.  There were even a few times on my first listen that I was actually able to predict what the next guitar riff was going to be!  On the other hand, sometimes there needs to be a certain level of playing it safe.  They (the band) may have felt if it ain't broke, to not fix it.    On the next album, I'd love to hear even more experimenation with different keys, LOTS of different grooves (are they totally incapable of playing something really fast?  Just to try to mix it up a bit?), and on the softer songs, not trying to force things too much.  Just be yourself.

0374115370|3.0|\\"Which of us is happy in this world? Which of us has his desire? or, having it, is satisfied?\\" (from \\"Vanity Fair\\", W.M. Thackeray, 1848)    In \\"The Bonfire of the Vanities\\", Tom Wolfe explores the theme of vanity. The exploration is set against an intricate plot in which the lives of upper class and lower class, Wasps and Irish, Jewish and Negros are set on a collision course following a random twist of fate by the book's protagonist -- Sherman McCoy, the aristocratic bond salesman.    But the exploration of vanity is not limited to the rich and wealthy. Wolfe delves into the vanity of the everyman: from the assistant DA absorbed in his physique to the English journalist who is ashamed of how his blazer is becoming \\"shiny\\", even a crack dealer, who goes through 2 pairs of Reeboks a week.     Thakeray explored the same theme in his work \\"Vanity Fair\\". While Thakeray writes in much greater detail and in a more florid style, Wolfe writes in the vernacular, liberally using language to bring to life the myriad of accents of modern day New York. \\"Talking\\" becomes \\"tawkin\\" for the Irish, \\"Sherman\\" becomes \\"Shuhman\\" for the southerners, etc etc.     Bonfire was pure entertainment. I couldn't put it down. On the other hand, it wasn't as satisfying or what I would rate as a \\"masterpiece.\\" Its a pulp fiction version of \\"Vanity Fair\\".

A child is deported to a concentration camp with his family, innocent of any crimes except being related to his grandfather, who is simply accused of an unnamed crime against the state. The grandfather is not held with them, and they receive no news of him. Also they know not for how long their imprisionment will last, or if it will ever end.<br /><br />How the family survives in the gulag of Yodok, how they capture and eat rats for a living, and how their lives continue, after being \\"freed\\" from the gulag.<br /><br />Years after, being suspected of \\"listening to a foreign radio station\\" the author finally leaves North Korea through China, makes his way to South korea, and eventually tells his story.<br /><br />Rivaling anything written about the Holocaust in Europe, this story reminds me of Armando Valladares' \\"Against all hope\\"<br /><br />A must read for anyone interested in foreign relations, and a clear indictment of one of the most heinous of current regimes.

B00005JNJT|5.0|This is a serious action film with an arthouse touch. As is well known, it was a majority consensus that the last two film's in the series were cheap parody's of the original comic series, that the caped crusader came dangerously close to becoming the \\"campy crusader\\", lost is some post modern haze. The last instalment (Batman & Robin) with George Clooney as the Batman almost brought Warner Bro's million-dollar Batman industry to a complete standstill. For some strange reason, Batman, even in the hands of capable filmmakers, lost its way, that is, until now.<br /><br />Christopher Nolan as director and co-screenwriter, known otherwise for his \\"thinking\\" films (Memento) has brought his cerebral sensibilities to the project, resurrecting Batman and presenting the character in the true light he deserves.<br /><br />Nolan approached the subject matter with the seriousness that is appropriate to Batman. He is a dark character, bordering on evil, using fear to combat evil. What Nolan has done is to give the audience the necessary background on Bruce Wayne, his seven year sabbatical in the mountains of Tibet, his training with the League of Shadows and his creation of the Batman, returning to Gotham city to fight the forces of evil.<br /><br />What makes Batman unique compared to other superheroes is the fact he does not have super powers but trains himself to do amazing feats, Wayne's incredible will to extend himself towards excellence, in the creation of an ideal, is truly inspiring. As Bruce Wayne has unlimited funds as a billionaire, he is only limited by his imagination, creating the ultimate \\"vigilantly\\", a dark force to be reckoned with in the battle against crime.<br /><br />The film has a league of excellent actors from Morgan Freeman to Gary Oldman playing a young \\"Commissioner Gordon\\"; this would have to be the first \\"good guy\\" that Oldman has played in over twenty years, and as expected, as one of the best character actors in the business, put in a stellar performance.<br /><br />Chris Bale as Batman soars above previous performances in the long series, making the character memorable and inspiring.<br /><br />One cannot write about this film without mentioning the \\"Bat mobile\\"; this car is simply astounding, zooming over the rooftops of the city. What one would give to have that car?<br /><br />I had high expectations for this film before walking into the theatre and found that it exceeded those expectations - without question this is a five star film.stellar performance.  <br /> <br />Chris Bale as Batman soars above previous performances in the long series, making the character memorable and inspiring.  <br /> <br />One cannot write about this film without mentioning the \\"Bat mobile\\"; this car is simply astounding, zooming over the rooftops of the city. B0007Y08QA|4.0|\\"The Machinist\\" is a film about guilt and innocence; its central character is obsessed with rules and regulations, cleanliness, the proper assignation of responsibility and blame. He says once that \\"a little guilt goes a long way,\\" and we believe him; it seems central to his existence. \\"The Machinist\\" is not an easy film to watch, but it is a very good one. It centers on the emotional unravelling of one man, Trevor Reznik, who is told several times in the movie \\"If you were any thinner, you wouldn't exist.\\" It is not something one needs to be reminded of; Trevor calls to mind the haunted skeletal forms of Holocaust victims. In a way this is fitting; he is the victim of his own private torture, trapped in a world of bleak gray and cold steel-blue. The grief that torments him - and has rendered him sleepless for a year - has literally eaten away at him, body and soul.<br /><br />Trevor is a machinist, a particularly astute one who knows every rule and keeps them all punctiliously. The job and his associates hold little in the way of comfort or pleasure; one senses that Trevor could use quite a lot of both. Once we see him reading, the closest thing to leisure time he seems to afford himself; he is reading Fyodor Dostoevsky's \\"The Idiot,\\" and one wonders if it is an ironic comment on his own existence, a lonely man adrift in a sea of cold hypocrisy. He is not an innocent, as is ultimately revealed, but he is definitely a victim.<br /><br />He has a standing arrangement with Stevie, a hooker who has apparently decided that this broken-down wreck of a man is worth her Heart of Gold. They do have sex - though one worries about him even then; his wraithlike form threatens to break if handled less than delicately - but their connection is more emotional than physical; he turns to her more than once to help him maintain the thin shreds he retains of his sanity. Jennifer Jason Leigh gives a subtle and touching performance here, conveying sympathy without condescension and kindness without treacle.<br /><br />He has another engagement, of sorts, with Marie, a kind-hearted waitress at the airport just outside town. He spends every night with her there, going out of his way to see her, drinking coffee and not eating the pie she serves him. She regards him, one senses, with the same sort of tenderness and nurturing that she does her young son. He certainly needs it. Aitana S&aacute;nchez-Gij&oacute;n, a virtual unknown in the States but deservingly respected elsewhere, gives another of the film's outstanding performances, as a woman kind-hearted but always just slightly intangible.<br /><br />There are several layers of metaphor at work in the film, particularly in the emphasis on \\"left,\\" which carries with it implications of the sinister and ominous. The hangman game progresses right to left; the Other Man in the photo appears on the left. Thrice Trevor encounters a Fork in the Road, and each time the left represents the more dangerous path. It is a small but lovely touch on the part of director Brad Anderson that only the third and final time Trevor is faced with such a choice does he choose the Right.<br /><br />The film's plot consists mostly of psychological games; strange post-it notes that resemble incomplete games of Hangman, a grimly dripping refrigerator, and a menacingly bald and grinning Man in Black are only a few of its elements. In some ways, particularly stylistically, it reminded me of \\"Memento,\\" although \\"The Machinist\\" is not as non-linear as that film. These elements are interesting the first time through, and gain even more meaning the second, when the reason for Trevor's disintegration is understood.<br /><br />And what a disintegration it is. Trevor makes a complete descent into Hell, which for him is the darkness of his own tormented soul. It is made believable by his cadaverous appearance, ghastly skin, eerily bright eyes; he is a man who looks not only as if he has seen Death, but keeps him constant company.<br /><br />Much has been made of the fact that the usually-buff Christian Bale lost 63 pounds - almost a third of his normal body weight - to play this role. One barely recognizes him here, particularly in contrast to his extremely well-cut physique in films like \\"American Psycho\\" or \\"Batman Begins.\\" Here his every move, every facial expression reveals the movement of bone beneath sallow, paper-thin skin. His clothes hang from his frame. Bale's normally attention-grabbing eyes gain an almost spectral intensity here, as they bulge glittering from their darkened hollows. His appearance is indeed so haggard that even the film's admittedly dramatic punchline almost fails to explain it, and at times it even distracts from the action as one begins to worry about him. Severely. One winces frequently, and I never quite got accustomed to his skeletal presence onscreen.<br /><br />Bale's performance, however, is complex and nuanced, and, like the drastic weight loss, goes far beyond the call of duty. Like his performance in \\"American Psycho\\" (also documenting a man's distancing himself from humanity) Bale here shows no shred of self-preservation, no hint of holding back anything from the role. He not only looks the part but inhabits it, bringing all the weight of his impressive talent to bear. It is this single-minded dedication to the character, and his virtuoso performance, that elevates an otherwise engaging but not mind-blowing psychodrama to a gloomy but impressive work of art.Bale lost 63 pounds - almost a third of his normal body weight - to play this role. One barely recognizes him here, particularly in contrast to his extremely well-cut physique in films like \\"American Psycho\\" or \\"Batman Begins.\\" Here his every move, every facial expression reveals the movement of bone beneath sallow, paper-thin skin. His clothes hang from his frame. Bale's normally attention-grabbing eyes gain an almost spectral intensity here, as they bulge glittering from their darkened hollows. His appearance is indeed so haggard that even the film's admittedly dramatic punchline almost fails to explain it, and at times it even distracts from the action as one begins to worry about him. Severely. One winces frequently, and I never quite got accustomed to his skeletal presence onscreen.     Bale's performance, however, is complex and nuanced, and, like the drastic weight loss, goes far beyond the call of duty. Like his performance in \\"American Psycho\\" (also documenting a man's distancing himself from humanity) Bale here shows no shred of self-preservation, no hint of holding back anything from the role. He not only looks the part but inhabits it, bringing all the weight of his impressive talent to bear. It is this single-minded dedication to the character, and his virtuoso performance, that elevates an otherwise engaging but not mind-blowing psychodrama to a gloomy but impressive work of art.

0140277447|5.0|First, let me say that I'm not an english major so I won't comment on the overall flow and quality of Iris Chang's writing, though I had no trouble with the book.  Second, one can not deny this event happened.  It has been cited, reported, filmed, and documented in so many other ways and in so many other venues that to deny it happened would be like denying Jupiter exists.  That leaves us with a difficult question - How many people did it affect, and how long did it last?  I believe Chang does a good job of outlining what she feels is the potential answer, but she does not force it on the reader.  She also presents other stated observations from the period, giving the reader the option to form their own opinion.  The rough figures range from 2,000 to 350,000 with the general consensus at 150,000-200,000.  I fear we may never know for sure but the bottom line remains, this was a terrible event by any stretch and a repeat for the Japanese.  What I mean by repeat is that throughout WWII (and past conflicts) the Japanese have had a steady track record of unbelievable events.  Burning 150 U.S. POW's to death in the Philipines, using British nurses as bayonet practice in Hong Kong, and one very long list from all over China, just to  name a few.  Don't just read this book and say, \\"Oh wow, that's terrible.\\" or from the other side, \\"That never happened, you can't prove it, this is all lies.\\"  Go out and get all the facts, find out all the angles, then work out the possibilities and determine your own conclusions.  For the record - I believe the number to be above 300,000, but as I stated before, we will simply never know for sure.

B00005R24K|5.0|I could watch nothing but The Evil Dead for an eternity and never get tired of it. B0002OERI0|5.0|The last thing this album needs is a long review, but it by all means deserves one. First off, a warning, this album is not nearly as punk as any of the old Green Day albums. I DID SAY GUITAR SOLOS!!!!!!) backed up by some rock hard hammering by Tre Cool filled in by edgy, in your fce bassline's of Mike Dirnt.  The Album starts off with \\"American Idiot,\\" a punk, political and guitar happy song which to me sounds like an introduction to one of the greatest albums of all time.  \\"Jesus of Suburbia\\" has everything you could possibly want in a 9 minute song.  A story along with drum solos, bass solos and guitar solos.  \\"Holiday\\" and \\"Boulevard of Broken dreams\\" are incredible fillers of the story filled with politics and emotion.  \\"Are we the Waiting\\" is a drum filled song with amazing vocals and emotional lyrics.  Once again the album is linked to the story.  \\"St. Jimmy\\" is the introduction of a new character, none other than St. Jimmy.
